The government agrees and is doing something to rectify that issue in the interests of the decision making. The opposition has proposed an amendment to the bill. However, it appears to be the same as or similar to the statement that Senators Bolkus and MCKiernan proposed in the amendment to the bill in their minority report in 1997. I reiterate the comments I made at that time, which are still relevant. The proposed amendment will create only more uncertainty and not remove it, as is claimed. To the extent that it actively encourages the courts to develop the common law on the basis of treaties, it will serve only to undermine the role of this parliament in legislating to give effect to treaties even further. In this respect, it should be noted that the amendment contemplates that the whole of the substance of a treaty could have effect by operation of the common law. This would have obvious consequences for the balance between the proper roles of the parliament, the executive and the judiciary. The amendment also fails to recognise that there are degrees of incorporation of international law in Australian law by statute. Giving international instruments the force of domestic law is but one of them. In addition, the wording of the principle as proposed by the opposition is totally unsuited for inclusion as an operative clause in the statute. Finally, it may have the effect of entrenching the operation of the Teoh doctrine-that is, it could give the exact opposite effect to the bill as introduced by the government. In summary, the amendment proposed by arose in the opposition would create uncertainty rather than resolve it. It would entrench the Teoh doctrine rather than set it aside. It would serve to further undermine the proper role of the parliament rather than reinforce it. This bill is of great importance in stemming the tide of illegal immigration to Australia, a subject addressed by the member for Fowler. Many cases involving the application of the decision in Teoh-indeed the Teoh decision itself-involve attempts by persons whose presence in Australia is unlawful to delay their removal from Australia. The opposition's inconsistency on this bill smacks of hypocrisy of the highest order. The opposition supports the government's efforts to control the latest wave of unlawful entrants into Australia, yet by opposing the swift passage of this bill as introduced, as the opposition has done, the opposition ensures that those who do arrive and remain in Australia illegally will continue to be able to frustrate the government's efforts to remove them. I take some heart from the fact that the opposition has clearly understood the need for this bill in the past. I hope that it will abandon its latest hypocritical and politically opportunistic position on the bill and support its passage in its current form. I look forward to the passage of the bill. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Consideration in Detail Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: ADMINISTRATIVE DECISIONS
text: by leave-I move opposition amendments Nos (1), (4) and (5): (1) Clause 5, page 3 (line 24) to page 4 (line 3), omit the clause, substitute: (5) Legal effect of International instruments It is hereby declared to be the intention of the Parliament that an international instrument (even though binding in international law on Australia) affects administrative decisions and procedures under domestic law only to the extent either that the instrument has the force of domestic law under an enactment or its substance has been incorporated into domestic law, in whole or in part, by the operation of the common law. (4) Preamble, page 2, (lines 14-22), omit all the words from and including “On 10 May” to and including “any such legislative expectations”. (5) Preamble, page 2, (after line 22), at the end of the Preamble, add: “Having considered the practical impact of the Teoh case, and the issues of principle involved, the Parliament of Australia believes that it is now necessary to reaffirm that an international instrument can have legal effect in Australian domestic law only to the extent that it is expressly incorporated by legislation, or its substance is incorporated into domestic law, in whole or in part, by the operation of the common law.” I have moved these amendments in the context of the opposition being on record in this debate as supporting the thrust of this bill. Indeed, our voting has just occurred in favour of the second reading of the bill. It is wrong to suggest that in any way, shape or form the progress of this legislation-I might add that it is up to the government when it introduces it into the House and the Senate-could influence the outcome of deportation orders or otherwise. In particular, in my speech on the second reading, I referred to the deportation guidelines, which specifically require the administrators to have regard, as a priority, to the rights of children involved. The Attorney might like to read my comments in that respect. It was worse than hypocrisy; it was opportunistic of him to even suggest that the position of the opposition in any way, shape or form restricts the deportation of criminals or illegal immigrants or otherwise. The facts of the matter are that the government's own guidelines specifically require their administrators to have regard in these circumstances-as a primary issue-to the rights of the children, as was the outcome of the Teoh case. Our amendments are, firstly, a specific statement of intention of the parliament consistent with the decision in Teoh's case and that stated intention is that international instruments do not have effect unless they have been incorporated into Australia's domestic law by enactment or unless they have been incorporated in whole or in part by the operation of the common law. That statement of intention ensures that parliament has the responsibility for enacting when international instruments apply-except in the third category, where the substance of an international instrument has specifically been incorporated into Australia's domestic law by virtue of a decision of a court in the development of the common law. With respect to the Attorney, he himself is quite ambiguous in the wording he uses, and we note his discussion of the operation of clause 7 of the bill, which the opposition accepts. Clause 7 says: To avoid doubt, section 5 does not affect any other operation, or use that may be made, of an international instrument in Australian law. According to the notes I made of the Attorney's speech, he acknowledged specifically that treaties can be incorporated into Australian law. If the Attorney is saying that treaties can be incorporated into Australian law only through an enactment of this parliament, he is wrong. The Attorney will be aware of the comments of the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, Chief Justice Brennan, in Mabo and Others v. Queensland (No. 2) in which His Honour said: The opening up of international remedies to individuals pursuant to Australia's accession to the optional protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights ... brings to bear common law the powerful influence of the covenant and the international standards it imports. There have been other instances where specific provisions of international instruments have been held to have been so significant that they have formed part of Australia's common law, and it is that situation that we are addressing. The specific failure of the government to address what they consider to apply in those circumstances itself leads to the uncertainty which the Attorney criticised. Far from creating uncertainty, we think our covering the situation of legislative enactment and also covering the incorporation of the substance of an international instrument into domestic law by virtue of a court decision as part of the development of the common law clarifies both situations, whereas the government will leave it quite ambiguous, which in itself is dangerous. (Extension of time granted) To make our position clear, we are supporting the intention of the bill. The intention of the bill is to say that it is the responsibility of parliament to advise and instruct administrators on which international instruments they are required to have regard to in performing their administrative duties while at the same time recognising that in this country we have a system of developing common law. We sit on top of a living common law that has developed over 800 years, and the common law is as much a part of our legal system as any enactment from parliament. We heard, in the passage I have just read, of one instance where the High Court acknowledged that the provisions of international instruments can be incorporated into Australia's common law. The common law, of course, develops by virtue of decisions of members of the judiciary by judges hearing cases. It is quite separate from and it does not apply to the Teoh decision, because in the Teoh decision the High Court held that as a matter of procedure-as opposed to substance of any particular treaty-administrators were required to have regard to international instruments where the administrator determined that those international instruments gave rise to a legitimate expectation. We agree with the govon the ernment that that outcome is quite inappropriate. Some 900 treaties have been ratified by Australia. It is quite unfair of and, indeed, poor administration on the part of any government to expect all administrators to be aware of the contents of all treaties. Indeed, those treaties themselves will in many areas have conflicting intentions or conflicting operations. Further, it is quite unfair and unrealistic to require administrators to then take another step-to make their own determination as to whether a particular treaty gives rise to a legitimate expectation. Again, we are at one with the government in saying that it is the role of parliament to instruct administrators what treaties are to apply to their decision making process and in what way they are to apply to their decision making process. The difference between what we are proposing and the outcome in Teoh is that point. The Teoh judgment said that, as a matter of procedure, administrators are required to have regard to all treaties for the purpose of going through that reasoning process which I have just described. We are saying emphatically that we regard that as inappropriate. In fact, it would be an abrogation of the responsibility of the parliament to allow that to continue to occur. However, in circumstances where a court has specifically stated that the substance of a treaty-that is the terms of the treaty-has been incorporated into Australia's common law, we say that administrators may be in a circumstance where, in applying the law, they will also be required to apply common law. Instances where the substance of a treaty has been incorporated in Australia's common law will be rare but, nonetheless, easily ascertainable by administrators having regard to decisions of judges of relevant Australian courts, which at a federal level would be the Federal Court and the High Court of Australia. In summary, it is quite inappropriate for the government to suggest that the opposition is in any way attempting to fetter or restrain efficient administration. To the contrary, we want to clarify how administrators perform their role. We believe our amendments more precisely achieve that and for that reason we move those amendments 1, 4 and 5 as circulated in my name.

Speaker: Mr WILLIAMS
Title: ADMINISTRATIVE DECISIONS
text: What the member for Barton said suggests that these amendments have been moved in good faith but, with respect, I think they are misconceived. The notion of incorporation into domestic law in the way that it is being used by the member for Barton is ambiguous, to say the least. To say that in moving these amendments the opposition supports the bill is really misleading. Opposition amendment 1 completely replaces the heart of the bill, that is, clause with an amendment in the form of a statement of intention. This is highly uncertain in both its drafting and operation and it would be likely to entrench and compound the effects of the Teoh doctrine rather than overturn it. If the opposition were serious about resolving the long standing problem created by the Teoh decision, they would have undertaken long ago to work with the government to find a workable solution, rather than shifting and changing positions at the last minute and introducing amendments without consultation. Opposition amendment 1 is substantially the same as the statement that Senators Bolkus and MCKiernan proposed in their minority report of 1997. As I said earlier, the same concerns which arose in relation to that statement arise in relation to the opposition's amendment. The proposed amendment will only create more uncertainty, not remove it as is claimed. Secondly, to the extent that it actively encourages the courts to develop the common law on the basis of treaties, it will only serve to undermine even further the role of this parliament in legislating to give effect to treaties. In this respect it should be noted that the amendment contemplates that the whole of the substance of a treaty could have effect by operation of the common law. This would have obvious consequences for the balance between the proper roles of the parliament, the executive and the judiciary. I would add: it is not the present law. Thirdly, the amendment fails to recognise that there are degrees of incorporation of international law and Australian law by statute. Giving international instruments the force of domestic law, as the amendment proposes, is but one of them. The wording of the principle as proposed by the opposition is really unsuited for inclusion as an operative clause in a statute. It may have the effect of entrenching the operation of the Teoh doctrine. It could therefore have the exact opposite effect of the bill as introduced by the government. The bill will not affect the use made by judges of international law, including treaties, as an influence on the development of the common law. This is made clear in clause 7 of the explanatory memorandum to the sec5, ond reading speech. The bill, in fact, is intended to have a very narrow sphere of operation. Clause 5, the operative clause, is squarely directed towards displacing the legitimate expectation which the High Court found arose out of a treaty. It does not say that treaties can no longer be used in the development of the common law. In summary, amendment 1 proposed by the opposition would create uncertainty rather than resolve it. It would entrench the Teoh doctrine rather than set it aside and it would serve further to undermine the proper role of the parliament rather than reinforce it. As to opposition amendment 4, which would omit reference in the preamble to the executive statements which have been made, the government believes that it is entirely appropriate to refer to these statements in the preamble. The government will not accept the omission of the relevant references. In the light of the comments I have made on opposition amendment 1, it will come as little surprise that the government will not support opposition amendment 5, as it simply foreshadows the opposition amendment to clause 5 in the same terms. Amendments negatived.

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: ADMINISTRATIVE DECISIONS
text: by leave-I move opposition amendments (2) and (3): (2) Preamble, page 2, (line 8), after "Australian", insert "domestic". (3) Preamble, page 2, (line 10), after "Australian", insert "domestic". These amendments are simple amendments which apply in the preamble where there is a reference to Australian law. We feel that it would be, for the sake of clarity again, more appropriate to refer to Australian domestic law because the situation, as the wording currently exists, is ‘an international instrument by which Australia is bound or to which Australia is a party do not form a part of Australian law unless those instruments have been validly incorporated into Australian law by legislation'. We think it is appropriate to refer to domestic law to avoid a situation where the phrase could be construed as also implying international law. It is a fact that Australia is bound by virtue of international law to its international instruments and we believe the insertion of the word ‘domestic' to distinguish that situation is appropriate and hence the reason for our amendments.

Speaker: Dr STONE
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: Murray-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage) (1.04 p.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. Fundamentally, the purpose of the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 is: to amend the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 to implement the 1996 Protocol to the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter, 1972 (the London Convention); and to amend the Sea Installations Act 1987 to remove the prohibitions on issuing, and varying, a permit that would authorise a sea installation to be located partly within and partly outside an adjacent area (which, generally speaking, is an area of Commonwealth waters adjacent to state coastal waters). Indicative of the Commonwealth's commitment to the preservation of Australia's marine environment, the bill will also include a number of additional amendments to the sea dumping act that are intended to simplify, encourage compliance with, and the enforcement of, the sea dumping act. The sea dumping act Under the sea dumping act, Australia fulfils its obligations as one of 77 contracting parties to the London convention. The London convention is aimed at promoting the effective control of pollution of the marine environment, by regulating the dumping of waste that is liable to: create haz2000 ards to human health; to harm living resources and marine life; to damage amenities; or to interfere with other legitimate uses of the sea. It embodies a framework for regulating: dumping into the sea-based on a list of substances for which dumping is prohibited, and a list of substances requiring special care; and 2000 incineration at sea-based on incineration guidelines. The London convention generally does not, however, apply in respect of: vessels and aircraft entitled to sovereign immunity under international law; the disposal of wastes or other matter derived from, or incidental to, the normal operations of a vessel, aircraft or platform; or the disposal of wastes or other matter directly arising from, or related to, the exploration, exploitation and associated offshore processing of seabed mineral resources. In summary, therefore, the sea dumping act currently regulates activities involving: dumping into the sea; incineration at sea; and loading for dumping into the sea or incineration at sea; where those activities occur either: from, or on, a vessel, aircraft or platform, in, or above, Australian waters; or from, or on, an Australian vessel anywhere at sea, or an Australian aircraft anywhere above the sea. The proposed construction of artificial reefs is also assessed, and permitted, under the sea dumping act. On 25 March 1998, Australia signed the 1996 protocol to the London convention, which entirely supersedes the London convention. Under the protocol, contracting parties are obliged to take effective measures, according to their scientific, technical and economic capabilities, to reduce and where practicable eliminate pollution caused by the dumping into the sea, or the incineration at sea, of wastes or other matter. The protocol embodies a more modern and comprehensive, and yet simplified, regulatory framework which aims to provide greater protection to the marine environment. The protocol prohibits incineration at sea, except in an emergency situation, and outright prohibits the export of wastes or other matter for dumping into the sea or incineration at sea. With respect to dumping, Annex 1 of the protocol provides a list of seven categories of wastes or other matter that may be considered for dumping at sea. These are: dredged material; sewage sludge; fish waste, or material resulting from industrial fish processing operations; vessels and platforms or other man made structures at sea; inert, inorganic geological material; organic material of natural origin; and bulky items, primarily comprising iron, steel, concrete and similarly unharmful materials, for which the concern is physical impact, limited to those circumstances where such wastes are generated at locations having no practicable access to disposal options other than dumping (for example, small islands with isolated communities). Except for in an emergency situation, no other substances may be considered for dumping. The general exemptions provided by the London convention, as I have outlined, are also incorporated in the protocol. As of 6 March 2000, there were eight contracting parties to the protocol. These were Denmark, the Republic of South Africa, the United Kingdom, the Federal Republic of Germany, the Republic of Vanuatu, the Kingdom of Spain, the Kingdom of Norway and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. Passage of this bill will implement the protocol nationally and satisfy Australia's domestic requirements for ratification. This action will reinforce the Commonwealth's commitment to the preservation of Australia's marine environment and reinforce Australia's standing as an international leader in responsible environmental management. Additionally, the bill will revise the offence provisions in the sea dumping act in relation to: dumping into the sea; incineration at sea; and loading for dumping into the sea or incineration at sea; and will include new offences in respect of: the export for dumping into the sea or incineration at sea; and the unauthorised construction of artificial reefs. A person engaging in activities constituting an offence against any of these revised or new offence provisions will be liable to a penalty of up to: 10 years imprisonment, a fine of 2,000 penalty units, which is approximately $210,000, or both, where the material volved in the commission of the offence includes seriously harmful material-and note that seriously harmful material will include radioactive material and any other material prescribed by the regulation to be seriously harmful material; two years imprisonment, a fine of 500 penalty units, approximately $55,000, or both, where the material involved includes non-Annex 1 material, and note that Annex 1 of the protocol, as I have outlined, lists the category of substances that may be considered for dumping under the protocol; and one year imprisonment, a fine of 250 penalty units, approximately $27,500, or both, in any other case. Corporations convicted of offences against these revised provisions will be liable, in accordance with the Crimes Act 1914, to up to five times these penalties. To ensure consistency between offence provisions in Commonwealth legislation, the bill will also apply chapter 2 of the Criminal Code to the offences under the sea dumping act. Significantly, the bill will also put beyond doubt that the Commonwealth has the responsibility for regulating the construction of artificial reefs. In the past the legislative authority to do so has not always been certain. This bill will apply the sea dumping act to Australia's exclusive economic zone rather than, as is currently provided, the Australian fishing zone. As well, this bill will limit current Defence Force exemption so that the Australian Defence Force will be required to comply with the act, except in an emergency situation or situation of armed conflict. The bill will also revise the exemption in relation to the naval, military or air forces of a foreign country in accordance with international law. The bill will simplify the rollback provision, section 9, which authorises the minister administering the sea dumping act to make a declaration to limit the application of that act in respect of a state or the Northern Territory where that jurisdiction has enacted legislation to implement the protocol. Recognising that officers of the Australian Customs Service have the expertise and are generally well placed to assist in the enforcement of the in- provisions of the sea dumping act, this bill will also amend the act to include those officers as ex officio inspectors for the purposes of the sea dumping act. Finally, the bill will also include a number of amendments of a machinery nature designed to simplify the sea dumping act. The Sea Installations Act The Sea Installations Act was enacted to ensure that sea installations installed in adjacent areas are operated with regard to the safety of the people using them and of the people, ships and aircraft near them; to apply appropriate laws in relation to such installations; and to ensure that such installations are operated in a manner that is consistent with the protection of the environment. A ‘sea installation' refers to any man made structure that when in, or brought into, physical contact with the seabed, or when floating, can be used for an environment related activity. An environment related activity is defined to include any activity relating to: tourism or recreation; the carrying on of a business; or the exploration and exploitation of the living resources of the sea, the seabed or the subsoil of the seabed. The Sea Installations Act does not, however, generally include fishing installations; some exploration installations, such as in the stallations and pipelines used by the petroleum industry; defence installations; or some cable installations. The act applies in respect of sea installations installed in an adjacent area of a state or affected territory which in general terms are the Commonwealth waters from three nautical miles out from the territorial sea baseline out to the outermost limits of Australian waters. The act does not apply in respect of sea installations located wholly within state coastal waters. Under the Sea Installations Act, the lawful installation and operation of a sea installation will require either: a permit to be issued; an exemption certificate to be issued; or a regulation to be made to exclude it from the application of the act. At present the Sea Installations Act prohibits the issuing or varying of a permit that would authorise a sea installation to be located partly within and partly outside an adjacent area. There is also some doubt about the validity of issuing an exemption certificate to authorise such a sea installation. The bill will amend the Sea Installations Act to remove these permitting prohibitions. This will remedy the unworkable situation of, on the one hand, proposals falling within the scope of the Sea Installations Act and, on the other hand, that act not conferring sufficient powers upon the administering minister to regulate these same proposals. In conclusion, passage of the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 will reaffirm Australia's commitment to the protection of the marine environment by implementing the 1996 protocol to the London convention. Passage of the bill will also strengthen the Commonwealth's power to ensure that all sea installations installed in adjacent area are operated with regard to safety and in a manner consistent with the protection of the environment. It will do this by enabling permit conditions to also be imposed in respect of installations located both within and outside an adjacent area. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: The opposition supports and commends the aims of the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000. The bill implements the 1996 protocol to the London convention and increases penalties for contraventions of the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act through amendments to the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 and the Sea Installations Act. These are positive and important developments in the environmental protection of our oceans. The purpose of the bill is to amend the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 in order to, first, implement the 1996 protocol to the 1972 Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter, which is generally referred to as the London convention; second, to clarify the Commonwealth's responsibility for regulating the construction of artificial reefs; third, to apply the act to the exclusive economic zone; fourth, to revise the offence, penalty and exemption provisions; fifth, to simplify the rollback provision for application to the states and the Northern Territory. It is good to see the government engaging in rollback, which there will be more of in the fullness of time. Sixth, it will include the Australian Customs Service as inspectors for the purposes of the act; and, finally, it will simplify provisions to make them consistent across the act. The bill also amends the Sea Installations Act 1987 in order to remove the prohibitions on issuing and varying a permit that would authorise a sea installation to be partly within and partly outside an adjacent area-that is, an area of Commonwealth waters adjacent to state coastal waters. However, the bill as it was originally introduced to the Senate included a number of weaknesses which the amendments that were an passed in the Senate set out to address. These primarily relate to the application of the precautionary principle and the definition of artificial reefs. For thousands of years we have viewed oceans as vast dumps for domestic and industrial garbage. Since the sea dumping act has been in operation, over 100 million tonnes of sediments have been dredged from harbours and waterways, and three million tonnes of industrial waste, 20 vessels, and 1,500 tonnes of munitions have been dumped. A number of materials were licensed for dumping which are now considered unacceptable, including munitions, car tyres, concrete, asbestos and industrial waste. These materials may never become evenly diluted into a weakened mixture and, indeed, ocean processes may even concentrate some materials. Impacts of sea dumping include: stress on marine mammals by loss of seagrass from smothering, death and disease from the dumping of contaminated materials and the loss of mollusc reproduction from contaminated sediments. The costs of dumping materials at sea are not generally borne by those who dump; they are borne by the fishing industry and the community at large. Recent decades, however, have seen a remarkable shift for the better in international attitudes the dumping of wastes at sea. This shift has been characterised by a move from an assimilative capacity approach, where the dilution effect of the oceans was thought to be adequate to mask the detrimental effect of the wastes, to the precautionary approach, where wastes should not be discarded where there is a risk of serious or irreversible damage. Concern for the health of the oceans has led to a number of international agreements which restrict the dumping of wastes and, indeed, the movement of hazardous wastes. The London convention was the first international convention to address ocean dumping and was ratified in Australia in 1985. The Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act incorporates the convention into Australian law. The London convention aimed to prevent indiscriminate disposal at sea of wastes liable to create hazards to human health, to harm living resources and marine life, to damage amenities or to interfere with other legitimate uses of the sea. The fundamental principle of the convention is the prohibition of dumping of certain wastes, the requirement of a specific permit prior to dumping of others and the demand for a general permit for the rest. The first two categories are determined by annexes. Although an important development, the convention was limited in scope. It applied only to waste from ships and aircraft and did not cover material dumped from a land source or the operational discharges of ships. Similarly, the offshore processing of seabed resources is neither covered by the convention nor covered by domestic legislation. The waters surrounding Australia's coastline are increasingly threatened by pollution from waste dumped at sea which Commonwealth laws seek to control. Some materials, such as those produced for biological and chemical warfare and radioactive material, cannot be dumped in Australian waters under any circumstances. The 1996 protocol to the London convention has considerably strengthened the provisions of the convention. In addition to a more restrictive list of substances which can be dumped, the protocol requires contracting parties to explore alternatives to sea dumping. Labor welcomes the increasing rigour to applied to the protection of the world's oceans. The 1996 protocol retains the objective of the convention and has captured essential measures propounded by the convention to prohibit dumping at sea. However, it does so while taking into account developments in technology for waste management that have occurred over the years, along with those anticipated for the future. The protocol discourages as far as possible any dumping at sea. Incineration at sea for the deliberate disposal of waste or other matter via thermal destruction is prohibited. Environmentally preferable land based alternatives are largely encouraged in order to avoid unwanted disposal of waste or other matter at sea. When I was a member of the Victorian parliament one of the issues I was involved in was the preparation of a management plan for the Gippsland Lakes. One of the critical issues being confronted at that time was the ocean outfall in the vicinity of the Gippsland Lakes and Lakes Entrance. People were very concerned about the impact of that particular ocean outfall. Indeed, in Victoria generally concerns have been raised about the impact of ocean outfalls and moves made, I am pleased to say, towards land based waste disposal systems to avoid the disposal of waste into the sea. The protocol recognises that current technology does not permit the disposal of certain categories of waste or other matter on land and that certain small island states lack the land mass for these land disposal facilities. In this respect, dumping may be allowed, but before such a decision is made candidate waste or other matter must first undergo a thorough assessment, including evaluation of a waste prevention audit, waste management options and identification of waste characteristics. The bill also extends the area to which the restrictions apply from the outer edge of the Australian fishing zone to Australia's exclusive economic zone, which includes also Australia's exclusive economic zone around Antarctica. The precautionary principle is critical in the area of oceans policy where scientific data is often incomplete. The bill needs to recognise the application of the precautionary principle as put in article 3 of the protocol. Senator Hill has stated that ‘the protocol incorporates the precautionary principle'-if there is any concern that the substance may harm the environment, it will not be dumped until testing has proved otherwise. However, this was not embodied in the original legislation and it is Labor's view this needs to be included in this legislation. The creation of artificial reefs is not considered dumping as recognised in the convention. It is essential that dumping is not proposed under the guise of reef creation. The definition of artificial reefs should limit artificial reef placement to the dumping of controlled materials as defined under the legislation. Labor supports the aims and objectives of this bill and the move towards a more protective marine regime. We have moved in the Senate a number of amendments and, of course, during this debate we will ascertain the government's position in relation to these amendments. So far there has not been any suggestion from the government that it does not support the amendments. I note in relation to these amendments, first, concerning the definition of ‘artificial reefs', that limiting the definition of artificial reef to a controlled substance a potential loophole exists to allow dumping of material other than that allowed under the protocol. Item 4 inserts a definition of artificial reefs into the sea dumping act. The concept of an artificial reef is not included in the London protocol but has been defined by the government under the bill. Secondly, there were Senate amendments relating to the negligence of an official. Clause 40A protects against legal action in relation to an act or omission of an official in relation to an artificial reef, even if the act or omission was negligent. The Senate amendment removed that omission in the case of negligence, I think for good reason. Finally, we come to the requirement to apply the precautionary principle. The bill as presented to the Senate by the government requires the minister to be satisfied that the material is capable of causing serious harm to the marine environment before making a regulation for it to be seriously harmful material. This would seem to be inconsistent with the precautionary principle as enunciated in article 3 of the protocol, which states: In implementing this Protocol, Contracting Parties shall apply a precautionary approach to environmental protection from dumping of wastes or other matter whereby appropriate preventative measures are taken when there is a reason to believe that wastes or other matter introduced into the marine environment are likely to cause harm even when there is no conclusive evidence to prove a causal relation between inputs and effects. Senator Hill has said that the protocol incorporates the precautionary principle. This was not in the bill as originally presented to the Senate and, therefore, was included in the legislation as amended by the Senate so that we have an amendment that requires the explicit application of the precautionary principle as required under the protocol. Before I conclude, I briefly note and register my concern that the government has slashed environmental funding for oceans across its portfolios by $150 million. This funding has gone from $294.7 million in 1999-2000 to $148.8 million in 2000-01 and will continue to fall to $81.3 million in 200203 and $72.5 million in 2003-04. This is a matter of concern to the opposition. We are by not concerned that environment program expenditure generally is dropping and that the government's commitment to environment funding is lacking. As we see the funding from the Natural Heritage Trust starting to dry up, the environment, including oceans, is not getting the commitment which it needs and deserves. Recently I spoke to a number of environmental groups in the Great Lakes area of New South Wales. That visit was organised by the member for Paterson, Mr Bob Horne, who is an energetic and environmentally aware member. They expressed to me considerable concern about issues of future funding based on the fact that the government's commitment to many of the environment programs and environmental repair programs had been based on its part sale of Telstra and that there was no ongoing commitment on the part of the government to provide the funding which these areas desperately need and deserve. I do want to register that concern. During the debate we will no doubt hear from the government concerning its intention regarding the Senate amendments and respond accordingly. As I indicated at the outset, we are supportive of this legislation and regard commitment to protecting our oceans from dumping as a matter of high priority. Therefore we welcome this legislation.

Speaker: Mr BILSON
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: It is my pleasure to rise today in support of the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000. I think it is the fourth occasion I have spoken in the parliament about the importance of our marine ecology and our coastal environment. It is an issue very close to my heart, representing the coastal electorate of Dunkley where the good folks of Seaford, Frankston, Mount Eliza and Mornington adjoin Port Phillip Bay and are close to some of the ocean beaches further down on the magnificent Mornington Peninsula. So it is an issue close to the heart of community I represent, myself and Australians more generally. We have in our management responsibility now 16 million square kilometres of ocean to care for under the exclusive economic zone arrangements. For people in the gallery and those listening at home, that is an area more than twice the size of our vast continent. We have an enormous responsibility for the proper care and management of a very large section of the earth's surface and what lies beneath it, and that is very much what we are here to talk about today. I want to also dwell on the point that as a nation we have an even greater responsibility for what is within that enormous area of the earth's surface. In Australian waters, within that 16 million square kilometres that we have responsibility for, as many as 18 per cent of the species found in the southern temperate waters are not found anywhere else in the world. We have the enormous responsibility of being custodian for 80 per cent of species in areas not far from your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker Adams. Those more temperate waters to the south of our nation down to Antarctica have species that cannot be found in any other place on our planet. Even the rich diversity of fish life and marine ecology in the warm and northern waters brought by the currents from the Indian Ocean and Pacific Ocean into our territory are something to behold. But 10 per cent of those species are endemic to our waters; so one in 10 of the species in those warmer waters can be found only in our country. It gives us an understanding as to why Australia has been at the forefront of marine management and coastal management and recognised to be so around the world. I guess we need to not only understand the environmental and ecological significance of the water but talk about the exclusive economic zone and our marine environment as a source of opportunity and wealth for our country into the future. The marine industries account at the moment for about $30 billion of economic activity a year, or about eight per cent of our gross domestic product, and are a major employer and exporter. I mentioned earlier that the coastal and the marine environment is close to home for the vast majority of Australians and is at the heart of the image and element of Australian society we celebrate abroad. We should look further into the future and think about biotechnology and what is within this area of our globe that I think is so poorly understood. We have talked about the 80 per cent of species found in our southern temperate waters that are not found anywhere else. We need to do more to understand those species. We do not know what mysteries they hold. We do not know in some areas what the mysteries of the depths of our oceans hold. It is our responsibility to understand and better manage those things. I am pleased to say that the Howard government is a world leader in this area through the development and implementation of an integrated oceans policy which takes account of planning, proper management and protection of our natural systems in our ocean environment. That is something that is also attracting considerable attention. We are the only country in the world that has an oceans policy and we have a right to be proud of that. Others are looking at how Australia does its work in this area to see how they can learn from our experience. We need to take a longer term view-and this is exactly what the government is doing through its oceans policy and then supporting it with a $50 million initial investment to commence the implementation of that policy. We can look abroad at what that ocean policy means on the ground. We have a national oceans ministerial board and enhanced planning, research and monitoring work. We also have improved assessment and management arrangements involving commercial and recreational activities as well as biodiversity protection. We are trying to involve the stakeholders-the scientific community, the private sector, the government and community-to make sure we have the best possible knowledge base for managing our marine environment. We can look at the government's work to implement the national representative system of marine protected areas to make sure that we have preserved forever, for future generations, areas of that marine environment that represent segments of that 16 million square kilometres that we have responsibility for managing. We are also trying to understand what the oceans do to themselves. The natural systems that occur in the oceans have an impact on our marine ecology and we are trying to better understand that through the terrific work of the CSIRO and other scientific bodies to make sure we know what the ocean actually does to itself and how it can bring about change over time. Closer to my electorate, the coasts and clean seas policy is further evidence of the government's commitment to marine protection and coastal management. Understandably, that is principally about state and terrihow tory responsibilities for coastal management that the Commonwealth government is supporting and in some cases leading through the development of pilot projects, assisting with proper coastal planning and tackling urban stormwater. In Port Phillip Bay, the biggest risk to the waterway on the doorstep of my electorate is stormwater. Most people think it is down the drain and it will not affect anything. That is not true. It has an enormous impact on the health of our coastal ecology, particularly in Port Phillip Bay. I have talked about efforts to tackle ballast water management and fight the introduction of exotic species before in this place. But today's instalment-and I use the term ‘instalment' in the context of this bill in the light of all those other initiatives I have spoken of-is about protecting our marine and coastal ecologies from pollution and the adverse impacts of marine structures and works. The bill, as has been explained by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage and the opposition speaker, the member for Wills, comes in two parts. Firstly, it amends the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act to bring it up to date with the evolution in international thinking. We heard both speakers talk about the London convention and how that has been superseded by the London protocol. That has new provisions in it to make sure that we are properly protecting our marine environment from a whole range of substances that people may think should be appropriately disposed of in our seas. Under the old arrangement there was a fairly narrow band of substances that were identified as hazardous and therefore could not be dumped. But there were some mysteries, doubts and confusion and-I guess for some people less committed to the environment than us-an opportunity to do the wrong thing and impact on our environment. I will talk more about that briefly. The second area that this amending bill addresses is the Sea Installation Act. We have heard about adjacent waters where a project may cross from Commonwealth areas of responsibility into state areas of responsibilities. There was some indecision about we could carry forward our obligations under the Sea Installations Act. An area probably close to your heart, Mr Deputy Speaker Adams, is the Bass Link project, highlighting how we cannot have a tidy project that neatly sits within one jurisdiction. There is the excitement that that brings for all the parties involved and for people considering investing in that type of project not knowing where the jurisdictional responsibility lies. So this is a problem here and now that we are hoping to tidy up and make more clear so that all parties, whether investors, conservationists, governments or elected representatives such as ourselves know where responsibility stops and starts. It takes away the doubt about whether the Commonwealth can enforce its obligations under the Sea Installations Act. I would like to talk briefly about how the issues that were canvassed in the act relate to everyday life for our communities. The Bass Link project is one example we spoke of. You would be aware of the interest in installing a hydro phone array off the south-west of Western Australia as part of our responsibilities under the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty-a listening device, so that if other countries are not doing the right thing under that treaty, we will get to hear about it, literally and figuratively, through that technology. That is another project that would have to wallow between the jurisdictional confusion that exists if the parliament does not pass this legislation. We want that proposal obviously to go ahead so we can monitor blast activity, but we do not want to run into a problem where the cable that returns that information back to our mainland crosses out of federal jurisdiction into state jurisdiction and the governments are looking at one another wondering how to move forward on that particular project. There are other areas in terms of the sea dumping act which are worthy of discussing. We know of our government's considerable efforts in border protection regarding migration and goods and contraband coming into the country. We are seeking to strengthen the enforcement effort by empowering Customs officers. They are out there doing things to protect the national interest at the moment and are appropriately skilled to monitor activities of this kind. If people are doing the wrong thing, they are there. They have an ex officio status to enforce the amendments we are seeking to have supported by the parliament and that will strengthen the enforcement effort. While staying on the enforcement effort, we should talk about the fines as well. There has been a significant escalation in the penalties for offences, supported by a clarification of those offences, so that they can be more readily understood and given effect to. So that is another bonus that is represented in this legislation before the House. My colleague spoke about the application of the legislation being extended into the exclusive economic zone. That is a major plus, moving out beyond Australia's fishing zone into that 14 million square kilometres that we have responsibility for, recognising that the marine ecologies do not neatly stop and start at jurisdictional borders. This is another benefit included in this legislation. The question of artificial reefs is something that is close to the hearts of people who are interested in things at Cottesloe surf beach in Western Australia. You do not want to have the community supporting a project to create an artificial reef, in this case to give more shape to the surf waves, as I understand it, not knowing where the jurisdiction properly lies. So the nation is fronting practical issues at this time and providing the necessary tools to make sure we can protect the marine environment, public safety and shipping as it moves through those areas. Another point I would like to briefly speak about is the question of defence activities around the country. We often host exercises where we have other countries coming into our territory to practise manoeuvres and the like. Here we have a tightening of the exemption that the defence department can rely upon. The blanket exemption that said Defence was important and therefore did not necessarily have to comply with these laws has been removed and replaced with a more restricted exemption that deals with emergency situations and episodes of armed conflict. So again the defence department, an arm of the federal government, is making sure it is being a good neighbour and good citizen in terms of environment management and protection of our marine ecology. But that is not the only example of how this bill supports good environmental citizenship. Our aircraft and our vessels travelling other parts of the world will also have to comply with these new tightened standards. So we are making sure that not only is Australia leading the way within our own area of responsibilities, but also our citizens and our vessels and our aircraft moving around the world are not able to operate under less responsible provisions than those they are required to operate under at home. So that is another constructive and practical example of how things can be translated into Australia's leadership position. There are a number of other areas I would like briefly to talk about. The main ones I have already covered. But the point I would like to leave with the parliament today is that this is not the first time this nation and this government have been leading the way with environment management, particularly in the marine area. Honourable members would be aware of Minister Hill's work, particularly in protecting whales in the southern sanctuary areas. We have been leading the way internationally and this is further evidence of what can be done by a coalition government and certainly the support from the opposition is welcomed. There is the question of implementing the precautionary principle. We can talk about the precautionary principle, or we can actually operationalise it. The government's commitment is to making sure that we operationalise the precautionary principle. Other speakers will be able to talk about that further. That is something that the opposition has addressed. It is certainly in the government's mind. But simply putting a bland statement in about that as an intent certainly does not give us the tools that operationalising it gives us where the act has provisions that make sure that that sound thinking has the legislative tools to back it up. I might leave my comments at that for today and congratulate the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, who is at the table, and if she could pass on my congratulations to Minister Hill. He is doing a fabulous job caring for our natural systems in this country. Our oceans and our marine environment are extremely important, as I outlined at the beginning of to my contribution today, and this is another instalment in making sure that the Howard government leaves the marine and ocean environment in the best possible condition for future generations.

Speaker: Ms HOARE
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: I am pleased to be able to speak to the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 as it comes to us from the Senate. Indeed, I am extremely pleased to have the opportunity to speak on environmental issues at all in this place. This government has been extremely lax when it comes to introducing legislation which is aimed at further protecting our fragile planet. But I must say that I do support this bill, one of the rare occasions on which the government has initiated legislation for the protection of the environment which does not rely upon the sale of national icons. The purpose of this bill is to amend the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 in order to implement the 1996 protocol to the 1972 Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter, known also as the London convention; to clarify the Commonwealth's responsibility for regulating the construction of artificial reefs; to apply the act to the exclusive economic zone; revise defence penalty and exemption provisions; simplify rollback provisions for application to the states and the Northern Territory; include Australian Customs Service officers as inspectors for purposes under the act; and to simplify provisions to make them consistent across the act. It is also to amend the Sea Installations Act 1987 in order to remove the prohibitions on issuing and varying a permit that would authorise a sea installation to be located partly within and partly outside an adjacent area; that is, an area of Commonwealth waters adjacent to state coastal waters. This bill is a direct legislative response by the government to its oceans policy, which was launched in 1998 during the International Year of the Oceans. As outlined in the oceans policy, this bill moves towards ratification of the 1996 protocol to the London convention and implements a total ban on industrial waste dumping at sea. It also imposes tighter regulations on artificial reef construction to protect the marine environment from pollution and to prevent hazards in the sea for navigation, commercial fishing and divers. Before I speak at greater length on the dumping of waste at sea aspect of this bill, I think it is timely to draw members' attention to the lack of environment measures contained in Treasurer Costello's fifth budget brought down on Tuesday evening. The government has slashed environmental spending on oceans across all portfolios by almost $150 million. It has gone from $294.7 million in 1999-2000 to $148.8 million in 200001 and it will continue to fall until 2004 when the Natural Heritage Trust Fund runs out. On Tuesday night while delivering his budget speech, the Treasure did not mention the ‘e' word once. Not once did he mention the environment in his budget speech. The decrease in funding in this budget for the Natural Heritage Trust comes at a time when our nation is facing the most challenging problems affecting our water systems, problems that must be solved in order for us to be assured that our children and grandchildren will be able to drink the water which flows through our inland river systems. Early this year the Murray Darling Basin Commission released its salinity audit and warned of undrinkable water in most inland rivers by 2020. In this budget that has followed the salinity audit most Australians were at least entitled to expect early measures to try to address dry land salinity. Australians had a right to expect that, but what they received a huge $60 million cut in the National Heritage Trust funding. This lack of commitment to the environment by this government has been exposed by its slashing the Murray Darling 2001 program by $6.4 million, slashing Bushcare by $12.5 million, slashing National Rivercare by $1.1 million and slashing Landcare, which is the real grassroots community based program delivered by mostly volunteers in our communities who have a commitment to the environment, by $3.9 million. As well as the cuts I have mentioned, the government has also cut funding to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, the Bureau of Meteorology and the Australian Heritage Commission. Another good indication of the government's failure to deliver on the environment is reflected in the greenhouse policy. In March this year it was revealed by Gwen Andrews, who is the Executive Director of the Australian Greenhouse Office, that Australia has failed to significantly reduce the projected levels of greenhouse gas emissions and thereby will be unable to reach greenhouse emission targets set at the Kyoto conference. I hope that when this bill has passed through both houses of the parliament its implementation will be monitored to ensure that some of the oceans policy commitments are fulfilled. Like many other areas of government, such as information technology, communications, industry, industrial relations and human rights, environmental issues must be placed in an international or global framework. The fragility of our international and national water system and the marine life within it needs to be respected, protected, maintained and nurtured. By ratifying the 1996 protocol to the London convention, Australia will take a positive step to fulfil its international obligations by implementing a total ban on industrial waste dumping at sea. The convention came into force in 1975 and was the first international convention to address ocean dumping. It aimed to prevent the indiscriminate disposal of wastes at sea and reflected the growing concern over the detrimental effects of such practices on marine life. However, the convention was limited in is that it did not cover the material dumped from a land source or operational discharges from ships. Moreover, neither the convention nor the domestic legislation introduced to incorporate it covered the disposal of waste related to the exploitation from offshore processing of mineral resources. Australia incorporated the convention into Australian law by introducing the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act in 1981 and ratified the convention in 1985. In effect, the protocol discourages any form of dumping at sea and obliges contracting parties to take effective measures to prevent, reduce and, where practical, eliminate pollution caused by dumping. For example, the deliberate disposal of waste by incineration at sea is prohibited. Environmentally sound land based alternatives are encouraged in an attempt to avoid disposing of wastes in a marine environment. Australia was one of the 42 contracting parties that adopted the protocol in 1996 and signed it in 1998. If this bill is passed, presumably Australia will confirm its intention to be bound by the protocol by moving to ratify it. The pollution caused by waste dumped at sea increasingly threatens our waters. We on this side of the House welcome the introduction of any measure that will strengthen the protection afforded the world's oceans. Every day I and my constituents in the electorate of Charlton live with the effects of indiscriminate disposal of contaminated wastes which have ended up in Lake Macquarie. Lake Macquarie, just south of Newcastle, is the largest coastal lake in the ern Hemisphere. Covering some 110 square kilometres with a total catchment of approximately 605 square kilometres, Lake Macquarie is characterised by fringing mangroves, wetlands and seagrass beds and has an abundance of aquatic life, including fish and water birds. Over the past 100 years Lake Macquarie has been subjected to the environmentally degrading commercial operations of forestry, mining, minerals processing and power generation located in its catchment and close to its shores. The lake also has supported local tourism and fishing industries. Some of these industries, combined with a huge increase in urban growth over many years, have placed the ecosystem of Lake Macquarie under increasing stress. We live with the effects of unnatural sedimentation and unnatural contaminants being discharged into the lake. These effects include the ecological impacts of sedimentation and nutrients from urban growth and industrial areas, existing urban and rural development and infrastructure around the lake. These impacts have included the reduced ventilation of shallow areas, the smothering of new shore habitats, elevated nutrient and algae levels in the water and the subsequent and progressive loss of vegetation around the lake and its tributaries. The historical impacts over the last 100 years have resulted in the accumulation and discharge of industrial waste. Some results of these impacts include a reduced ability to navigate the lake and its tributaries because of its accelerated sedimentation. We also have damage to seagrass beds caused by this sedimentation. Unfortunately, some of the recreational users enjoying boating and fishing activities continue to dump bait bags and drink and food containers which further contaminate the lake. Such a delicately balanced ecosystem cannot tolerate such impacts any longer. We must be able to remediate and preserve Lake Macquarie for many future generations. All residents of Lake Macquarie were pleased that the New South Wales state Labor government has made real commitments to help in the remediation process. In 1999 the Premier, Bob Carr, set up the Lake MacSouthquarie task force to provide an integrated estuary and catchment management framework for Lake Macquarie to provide a healthy, sustainable lake for a quality lifestyle. Although the task force provided us with a three-year action plan it has been emphasised that federal and state governments must provide ongoing funding past that three-year period. It has been estimated that the total cost of the remediation to fix the lake after 100 years of waste dumping and waste contamination is $40 million. The task force stated in its report that any lesser amount was inadequate. All sectors must take ownership of the past degradation and contribute to fixing it up. Out of all those sectors, the federal government is the largest and most able to contribute. What has the coalition government contributed so far? The answer is $500,000-half a million dollars. The lake needs $40 million to fix it-and the federal government provides half a million. To the minister for the environment, the people of the Charlton electorate thank you-but please, sir, can we have some more? Lake Macquarie City council has applied for funding to address the most pressing problem for the lake; that is, stormwater runoff. The council has applied for nearly half a million dollars from the government. I understand the application is currently with the minister. I make a personal plea to the minister in this debate to provide favourable and positive consideration of the council's current application and any further applications for funding to clean up Lake Macquarie. I take this opportunity to congratulate Janssen, who is employed by the New South Wales state government as Lake Macquarie catchment coordinator. Jeff has a good strong background in environment matters as well as a personal commitment to the protection of our natural environs. Jeff is a long-time resiread it. dent of Lake Macquarie. I know he wants the lake protected for his children and all future generations. Well done so far, Jeff, and you know you will continue to have my full support in your efforts to clean up our lake. In conclusion, while supporting the bill and everything it represents in relation to our international obligations towards the protection of our planet, I call on this government to start addressing some of the domestic problems that exist here and now and must be fixed. Our local waterways must also be protected. Debate interrupted. NA

text: I thank the honourable member for Kalgoorlie for his question. When it comes to Australia's fascinating outback, he of course understands it as well or better than anyone else in the country. His is a huge area with perhaps less than 200,000 people. It is quite unique. The largest city is probably Kalgoorlie, but it spreads across much of mainland Australia and sees people living in the most extraordinary, sometimes very difficult and certainly often very unique circumstances. At the same time it has to be said that it is a region of great economic and social importance to the nation. There is no doubt that the budget initiatives that were announced in this place a couple of nights ago by the Treasurer are of very real value to the outback and the people in the outback of this country. The package of $1.8 billion does actually contain a couple of specifics that I would like to draw people's attention to. For example, helping people in isolated regions access education for their children on a reasonably equitable basis, keeping in mind that most of us take for granted that, one way or another, we can get our children to the school gate pretty much for free. That is simply not the case for people who live in some of the most isolated regions on earth. The extra assistance through the isolated children's allowance scheme has been very widely welcomed indeed. So, too, has the better access to Youth Allowance, with the further discounting of business assets. Mr Speaker, another important aspect of the budget is that we are doubling funding for the remoter Service Subsidy Scheme. That is a very, very important aspect of life in remote parts of the country. I see that another memhas ber from the far north of Queensland, Warren Entsch, well understands how important this is. Indeed, as the ICPA has said, often the scheme is a vital link and the only sustainable communication link at all for many people in the far flung and remote parts of this country. Mr Speaker, $260 million over 13 years under the regional equalisation plan will ensure that remote Australia shares in the benefits offered by the world of digital television and datacasting services. Five million will be provided to subsidise the transmission costs of community based self-help broadcast groups in remote areas and that will ensure that remote communities have the best possible access to broadcasting services. The Year of the Outback in the year 2002 will be supported by all states and territories, by tourism-Jackie Kelly, the minister for tourism, has been a very enthusiastic backer of this planned year of activities-the private sector is involved, as is the tourism industry itself. We will be contributing financially to this great effort to raise people's awareness of the outback in terms of investment opportunities and in terms of tourism potential. The Community Development Employment Program, the CDEP scheme, will be expanded by 1,500 places. That is of enormous value to many, many people in rural and regional areas but particularly in remote parts of the country. These budget measures add to very important initiatives under way. We know that the ALP want to abandon commitments on tax reform. One of the things that has not been drawn out properly is the enormous importance of abolishing the impact of embedded taxes on exports. Outback Australia is an export based economy and we are crippling ourselves, one hand tied behind our back, with a tax system that they continue to insist is modern and up to date. Mr Speaker, $4½ billion of that embedded taxation in our exports sector will be washed out by tax reform. They have also of course continually opposed our reforms on transport fuel. One of the great killers of economic growth and development in far flung regions of Australia is the high cost of transport, and they have opposed, every inch of the way, our attempts to reduce transport costs, which will now come into place from 1 July. Mr Speaker, they have also sought of course to stand in the way of such vitally important measures as those that have resulted from the T2 sale of Telstra-$150 million for untimed local call access to remote areas; that is a very valuable reform coming up indeed. Let me return briefly to the importance of health flights. If you live in a far flung part of this country, health is of critical importance, and everywhere today I have noticed the commentators saying we have got the priority right. The attention to health in rural and gional and remote areas is important, is needed and should head the list. I note the laudatory remarks that are being made about my colleague the minister for health are very widespread indeed. The National Rural Health Alliance have warmly welcomed the range of new initiatives. They are going to write to you, Minister, to congratulate youas indeed they might. We see Dr David Mildenhall, National President of the Rural Doctors Association-I think in fact a constituent of the member for Kalgoorlie-has said that the Howard-Anderson government has built on ‘the Wooldridge ministry's previous good work' in the bush. Then we have Dr Ken Mackay, New South Wales President of the Rural Doctors Association, saying today: The reason that this has come together is that health minister Michael Wooldridge listened he was out in regional areas. So I can tell you one thing: if there is one group in the Australian community that absolutely supports and stands rock solid behind the minister for health, it is rural and regional and remote Australia. There is no question whatsoever that there are some people within the trade union movement and within the Australian Labor Party who are anxious to destroy the system of enterprise bargaining which was introduced in Australia by our predecessors in the early 1990s and which has been very effective. The Prime Minister today spoke of 699,000-plus jobs being created-nearly 700,000 jobs. One of the reasons for that is that we have been reforming the workplace relations system, and the introduction of enterprise bargaining was an important element of that. Whilst we had our many criticisms of the reform legislation introduced by the member for Kingsford Smith, we were, however, always consistent in saying that, to the extent that enterprise bargaining was introduced, it was the right policy for this country. In 1996 not only did we endorse the concept of enterprise bargaining but also this parliament went further and saw the entrenchment of enterprise bargaining in both the unionised and nonunionised sector. Such a threat is this campaign-so I am informed by the media-that it is referred to in Steve Bracks's office as ‘Apocalypse Now'. They ought to be concerned because many jobs will be lost unless these campaigns to knock off enterprise bargaining are in some way resisted. This government's policy is to introduce further measures to the Workplace Relations Act to achieve the retention of the system of enterprise bargaining. We intend to give new powers to the Industrial Relations Commission to prevent the industrial action associated with pattern bargaining. New powers will be given to the commission to act in a timely way to require a return to work. We will also provide the commission with a new power to order a cooling-off period where it believes that to be appropriate-an idea which even Steve Bracks, the Labor Premier in Victoria, thought was sensible only a month or so ago. Lastly, as the fourth of four measures, we intend introducing by legislation today a measure which will ensure that the states' supreme courts continue to have jurisdiction to deal with common-law matters, which they have long held but which has been subject to anti-suit applications in recent times. To give you a sense of the threat which is now being mounted by the ACTU and some unions, Doug Cameron, for example, said recently: It is a simple fact that the ALP cannot survive win government without the support of trade union members. Julius Roe from the AMWU said: I support militant action. You can't win things without militant strugglean obvious reference to the widespread industrial action and chaos that some of these union leaders are intent on bringing upon the manufacturing sector. Craig Johnston, also from the AMWU, said: The employers make us out as mad. But if we were mad, we wouldn't have won all these disputes. We've been threatened with fines and jail, but we haven't paid and we aren't in jail. Even within the Labor Party, you must realise that there are some people who are intent on destroying a system which you yourselves supported. The member for Kingsford-Smith, for example, back in August 1993, at a lunch hosted by none other than the now shadow minister, said this about the move to enterprise bargaining: We are unquestionably moving towards a system in which the primary emphasis is on workplace bargaining underpinned by awards, a system where for the majority of employees wages and conditions of work are covered by workplace agreements: agreements between workplace participants, agreements that are tailored to the needs of individual enterprises and based on improving the productive performance of those enterprises. I am encouraged by the commitment of all parties to this objective. The test today is whether or not the Leader of the Opposition can stand up to the ACTU and remain committed to a policy which has demonstrably provided great benefits to the Australian people: 700,000 jobs and much improved productivity performance since we have been in. He also well knows what happened the last time there was such a technological revolution for people in country areas, from analog to digital. That was in the early 1990s when the Labor Party handed over to digital transmission broadcasting techniques and broadcasters without any transition arrangements, without any safety net for country people. It took this government with its CDMA initiatives to protect the interests of country people and ensure that they had access to the latest telephone technology and associated technologies. Now we are doing it again in regard to digital television and datacasting services. We are providing up to $260 million for the regional equalisation plan, with an allocation of $22 million this year, which represents 50 per cent of the estimated costs of digital conversion for regional broadcasters. It is a partmeeting nership between regional broadcasters and the government. We also have a partnership with rural communities. We will ensure that community based self-help retransmission groups are able to obtain access to transmission sites at less than commercial rates. This is a $5 million matching of the $5 million funds from NTL, the new owner of the national transmission network. That will help smaller communities to establish and operate equipment to retransmit commercial and national television and radio services that they otherwise would not have access to. At the same time we are injecting very significant funds into the public broadcasters ABC and SBS. ABC will receive an additional $36.5 million and SBS almost $30 million for digital equipment over and above previously announced funding. We have also given a commitment to fully fund the cost of digital television transmission and distribution. So it is a very substantial commitment to the ABC and SBS as they enter the digital era. You can see the contrast between the Labor Party when in government and the coalition parties when in government. We do not deprive country and regional viewers and users of the latest technology or of access to all the advantages it can bring.
