Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: CARE
text: I thank the House. I move: That this House censures the Minister for Health and Aged Care for: (1) The clear evidence (both direct and corroborative) provided in the Auditor-General's report that he disclosed a Budget proposal at a on 6 May 1998, when he had a duty as a Commonwealth office holder not to do so; (2) The misleading and false statements he has made to the House on this matter; and (3) The negligent and incompetent handling of the entire MRI negotiation process in 1998 for which he, as Minister, was ultimately responsible. If this were the British House of Commons, I would not be standing before this dispatch box on this side of the House with this report in my hand. The minister would be standing at that dispatch box on that side of the House with this report in his hands and one other document-his resignation statement. If this was a parliament that truly upheld Westminster standards, when the Auditor-General's report came down that would have been the end of it; it would have been all over and what has been effectively close to two years of lies, prevarication, obfuscation, dishonesty and deceit in this House would have come to an end. That is what would happen in the United Kingdom. Even under the abbreviated standards of the previous Howard government in the last parliament I feel confident that that same thing would have happened. There has never been in my 20 years in parliament an Auditor-General's report dealing with matters of administration in the portfolio of a particular minister with which the minister was directly and intimately concerned that has come down with such damning conclusions in relation to the minister's handling of that portfolio. It is absolutely extraordinary. One or two of our ministers went during our time and one or two of them went on the basis of Auditor-General's reports. But they were nowhere near as comprehensive in damning the administration of a minister as this report has been. Nor were they accompanied with the level of prevarication that has gone on in the preliminaries to this in parliatoday-he ment, where the member for Jagajaga has had to put up with lying mockery month after month in question time in this place. Because she is tough, diligent and dogged, we have come to this point where something approximating the truth is before us. I say ‘approximating the truth', and that is not a reflection on the Auditor-General, because I believe most firmly that someone lied to him-and it was not the four radiologistsabout the content of that meeting. It was the minister, and every piece of circumstantial evidence points to this. For ministers to go in this place does not require a criminal standard of proof. That is an absurdity. You do not go on trial here for maladministration where, at the end of the day, there has to be absolutely no remaining element of doubt for a conviction to be secured. We operate on the basis of common sense, experience, our understanding of the political process and our understanding of levels of ministerial responsibility. That is how we operate in this parliament. It is not a court and nor does the Auditor-General run a court. But he has found, on the balance of probabilities-and I can see that he could find no other way-that there is no other conclusion to be drawn but that the minister or one of his officials in the minister's pressentence, ence-but most probably the minister-so informed that group of radiologists. This was a group who had been portrayed-I might say by the minister-as attending a ‘cheerio' meeting to thank them. Remember, that was an answer to one of the questions: ‘This was just a little session to thank them.' I might say that the Auditor-General does not treat it like that at all. This was a formal business meeting at which matters of business were discussed. The matter of business that was discussed on the initiative of the minister or one of his officials, and probably the minister in the case of one of them, on the majority view of the people attending that meeting was the date of closure on contracts related to whether or not you secured medical benefits for MRIs. You just have to go through this thing point by point to see that is true, and to see the minister's half-baked answers here has continued the pattern. For example, look at paragraph 2.27, where it says: All College members who attended the meeting of 6 May 1998 agree that the Minister did not reveal Budget measures. It goes on: However, they are all of the view that, in the context of the College expressing concerns about site restrictions, there was discussion of the possibility of including machines on order as of Budget night, although this was discussed only as an option. All but one member considered that the issue was raised by the Minister (the other has stated that it was raised by the Commonwealth, but could not recall by whom). The evidence of the College representatives indicates that the College expressed concerns regarding enforceability if the Government included machines on order as a supply control and one representative recalls assurance being given in this regard. I will tell you what the other evidence is. You have the four radiologists attending stating it; and the minister and his myrmidons stating that no such thing was raised. However, I might say that in answer-before he remembered what he was saying-to a question from Fiona Reynolds on precisely this point this morning, he started out by saying, ‘Cabinet authorised me to negotiate the point of closure.' Then suddenly having remembered what he had actually confessed to in that he quickly backed away to the formula, leaving it just hanging out there, indithe cating that he knows the truth of this matter. But despite the 4-3 verdict of those attending the meeting in that regard, we have the further evidence the next day of the incoming President of the College of Radiologists who was taken aside and briefed by the people who had attended the meeting on what he had been advised of. So we have then what any police investigation of this process would suggest-because this was evidence not in memory now of times back then, but the immediate reaction of the person the day after the meeting took place-that is, that a reasonable inference could be drawn that information was provided to them at that meeting and then the cornucopia flowed. Radiologists who attended the meetingand they have given evidence on oath-revealed that that minister discussed the sensidefence tive measure. And that is evident from the paragraph I have just read here. The sensitive measure, it has to be remembered, had only been recommended to the minister the day before, on 5 May 1998, by the department. All those orders-and there were not that many of them; there were a few-in place before 5 May had not occurred against a background in which information that caused them to do that could conceivably have been tainted by this decision about which, on the day before the meeting, the minister had written to the Prime Minister asking for be incorporated as the option to be agreed on budget night. There is a degree of slipperiness here, I have to tell you, and it is the way in which the minister tries to defend himself on the budget issue. Because there was still not a finalised option on what actually was a budget measure, his sleight of hand is to ‘It wasn't strictly a budget measure on that night.' What he is saying is ‘not strictly a budget measure on that night'. There is in the budget a proposition which will extend, under certain conditions, a medical benefit to the owners of MRI machines for the utilisation of those machines. That is there in the budget. There is a question of who should qualify for that-an obvious incorporation within any budget decision. There is a piece of correspondence between the minister and Prime Minister, which would be stamped, going to the Prime Minister: ‘Cabinet in confidence'. That is what would be on top of the letter sent between the minister and the Prime Minister, sent on the fifth and finally replied to by the Prime Minister on the 11th. But you had a decision already in the budget, acknowledged by the minister, that there would be a benefit applied, effectively, to the ownership of the machines. And you have a piece of correspondence associated with that budget decision not yet quite finalised, but totally within the framework of budget consideration. It was not a matter that was suddenly looped into the budget on 11 May. It was a matter already there in the budget and this is a final detail associated with it. On that strand, that thin reed, the minister rests his that he did not actually leak a budget matter. If it had been a public servant who took information from a minister's letter and went to another person in the community and divulged that information to that person in the community, who subsequently took a benefit from it, what would happen to that public servant? If that were to be proved in a court of law, he would go to jail. That is what would happen to that public servant. He would go to jail. He would be regarded as having divulged an official secret, divulged it in the worse possible circumstances, and diit to vulged it in a way from which somebody could profit. I think there is in ‘interesting' feature about this date of 5 May and who was actually responsible for all this circulating in his mind. There is in fact a suggestion by one public servant that the issue of a cut-off date applying to machines ordered but not delivsay, ered before budget day was something circulated earlier in the department by the minister himself. The Auditor-General thought enough of this to incorporate it, although that suggestion was repudiated by other public servants in the evidence and, therefore, he dismissed it and left it standing that this particular final qualification was something that came forward from the Public Service to the minister, late in the piece, and things flowed from that. I have a very strong suspicion, reading between the lines, that the minister was working on this particular matter himself for some considerable period of time and that it was not so significant to folk in the department is of course the reason why it did not leak before 5 May. The Auditor-General found that it was a departmental suggestion passed to the minister; I reckon it was the minister in for his chop. Let us understand the situation of the Auditor-General here and the very tough findings that he has arrived at. The Auditor General is not a lurid public official; he is an extreme public official. He is a very cautious public official and he expresses himself in the quietest terms, even when he is revealing or dealing with the most heinous of scandals. That, of course, is the language of this report. But because there is no extremity in the language and because there is from the Auditor-General a very measured, clear-cut and deliberate arrival at the conclusions ought not blind us to the fact that he, as our principal parliamentary officer on audit of government activities, is advising this parliament of exactly the direction in which it should go. He understands why the minister is going to defend himself to the death on this. The Auditor-General understands that the discussion of this proposed budget measure at the meeting on 6 May 1998 was highly improper, given the minister's knowledge of the stake of this issue in correspondence between himself and the Prime Minister at that stage of the game. I just want to go through another aspect of the findings of the Auditor-General on the question of these 33 machines. The Auditor-General points to the possibility that folk could have come to a decision about these matters on a punt. He includes that as a possible reason. He arrives at a balance of probabilities conclusion that it must have been a leak from the meeting-a balance of probabilities suggests that there are other particular conclusions he could come to. But when he considers the incoming President of the College of Radiologists, when he considers the evidence of the four and, then, when he considers the surge in the number of machines, he can really come to no other conclusion on the balance of probabilities. The Auditor-General said, and I will read this part in full: There was a surge of orders for MRI machines immediately before the budget. Statutory declarations provided to the HIC indicated that there were 33 machines ordered in the four working days from 7 May to Budget night 12 May 1998. The minister will defend himself by saying that there was knowledge out there in the ether for some considerable time because the possibility of the application of medical not benefits to the MRI machines was a matter of discussion and general knowledge out there in the community for some considerable time before 5 May. And so there was, apparently, from what has been said in the Auditor General's report. This general ether discussion about the possibilities comes to this, and the report goes on: Prior to this, there had been six ordered in April, seven in March, none in February, and three in January. The surge in orders prior to the Budget compares with a total of some 60 public and private machines operating at that time. Go through that: there was a tiny numbernot a tiny number, but a number considerably less than 33-in that ambience of generalised discussion. But why was it so relatively slow? The proposition circulating in the department at the time-or the option circulating in the department at the time-would have had you believe, in all probability, that on the night this was declared in the budget and benefits were extended to machines, they would be benefits extended to machines operating on the night of the budget. That is the point: benefits extending to the machines operating on the night of the budget. Though these machines can be readily obtained, they cannot be obtained that quickly. The point was: the minister was unhappy with this situation. He feared that there would be a conclusion drawn amongst those who had been putting machines on order that they were unfairly disadvantaged by the time line that saw them not brought in under the bar on the night of the budget. So this was the critical decision: to go beyond machines extant on the night of the budget to machines ordered. A machine involves a considerable investment-$3 million. Very few people around this place would punt $3 million, no matter how wealthy they are, on the basis of a chance. But anyone with half a brain running a radiology service and knowing how massively enhanced a radiology service is by an MRI machine would punt on a certainty. In fact, if he does not punt on a certainty dead. If he does not punt on a certainty his practice is an inferior practice from that point till hell freezes over. That is the position doctor in those circumstances. That is why this information was so incredibly sensitive. That is why it should have been held and not blabbered by an ignorant, worthless minister. What happened, of course, was precisely that. The only reason why this has been teased out is that there were quite a substantial number of radiologists who were not in on the joke. Widespread though the knowledge became after the minister's meeting, it was not that widespread. It was widespread enough to produce 33 machines, many of them in the hands of those involved in the negotiations, but not widespread enough to incorporate everybody else who saw their practices therefore rendered second rate at the end of it. No sensible person reading this report, nobody with any experience as a public official reading this report and no-one with any common sense reading this report in the community could come to any other conclusion than the one the Auditor-General came to: that, on the balance of probabilities, the information leaked from that meeting; and that the only persons who identified anyone discussing it at the meeting were the four radiologists about the minister. They cannot have known of the minister's letter, intentions and options unless the minister told them. An intelligent guess would not be good enough, but an intelligent guess suggests that this minister should go. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: CARE

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: CARE
text: The Auditor-General has had a thorough investigation over a period of six months into the processes around the government's decision to bring MRI machines into Medicare. This investigation has examined up to 135 people on oath or affirmation. It has had access to all departmental documents. It has had access to my diary. It has had access to any other records that have been required. I have given he is evidence on oath, and I have made many statements in this parliament. I have to say on reflection, and on looking of a at this measure, that it certainly shows up some areas of deficiency in administration in this area. I do not believe that is generally the approach in my department, and I do certainly take responsibility for fixing that. I can understand why Labor are upset, because for more than a year now they have been going around the corridors of this place and around the press gallery making allegations about a conspiracy, making allegations of a budget leak that advantaged certain individuals and making allegations of secret meetings. None of those things have come to pass. The Auditor has found that I observed the highest standard of probity, that there were no such secret meetings, that there was nothing outside the formal negotiation process and that all the allegations that have been made-and the overblown nature of the allegationshave proved to be completely false. So the ALP has some difficulty arguing that, on the one hand, all this should rest on the word of a number of radiologists and, on the other hand, that somehow these same honest and honourable radiologists must have then gone out and talked their heads off against what clearly they had said they would not do. Those two things are contradictory, and it brings down the entire argument of the opposition. This censure motion looks at three issues. All issues I think are worthy of comment. On the first issue, that there was clear evidence provided in the report that I disclosed a budget proposal: the report says very clearly that everyone at the meeting agrees that I did not disclose what was in the budget. The second matter of censure of me is that I have made misleading and false statements. I challenge the opposition on any occasion to show where, on the best available knowledge that anyone could have had at the time, anything I have said has been either misleading or false. They censure me on the negligent and incompetent handling of the entire negotiation process. It is reasonable for them to attempt to censure me on that, but in the end would rather focus on the positives: we now have machines available right around Australia; 140,000 Australians have been able to get access to MRI scans for serious neurological conditions, and that they have been able to do that without paying $600 to $800, as was the case under Labor-it is now $40 to $50; rather than having to wait five months, which was the case prior to this measure, they now wait one to two weeks; and, there are 17 machines located in rural Australia. This is a significant achievement, and it is one for which many Australians are grateful. Looking at the process, I have to admit that it could have been better handled. We were trying to do something that had not been done before. In one sense, it was the cutting edge of policy because, rather than just putting something on the Medicare Benefits Schedule and letting it rip-as happened with CT scanning-we were attempting to bring clinical guidelines into the Medicare Benefits Schedule and have a process whereby we would pay for those scans that could be backed up on the basis of evidence. This is not something that we have done before. We also were attempting to introduce a major technology for which there was very great demand and to do it in such a way that would not lead to a very large blow-out. As a result of this, there is no doubt that the Commonwealth was exposed to some risk, and we acted very quickly when we had concrete evidence of that. The Auditor-General could not find that a single scan had been done unnecessarily. The Auditor-General could not find a single scan that had been done for a neurological condition that should not have been done. So the fact is that there has not been a single dollar wasted on this. Every scan that has happened has happened out of necessity. Labor makes several quite incorrect accusations. They say that the supply side was somehow my issue and that I was working on it. That is completely contradicted by the departmental secretary in a letter that I have previously tabled in the House and is repeated on page 146 of the Auditor-General's report. I asked the secretary specifically: was I there any evidence of this at all? He replied: You asked whether the Department provided advice to you on restricting eligibility of MRI machines for MBS purposes which you had not accepted. I have not been able to find any evidence of your rejecting our advice in this area. The Officers most involved assure me they never advised that you should limit eligibility to machines then operating in the country. A detailed advice on this matter was provided to you on 5/5/1998. That is when I first became aware of it. I do have recollection of this, even though it was more than a couple of years ago, because my department was concerned at the time and I remember asking them what options we had. They were the ones who raised it with me. There is the continual allegation that there was a budget leak. I think there is a very clear explanation for what happened in this whole process. Again, in interviewing, under oath or affirmation, all the people who were involved in this, there is no evidence of a budget leak at all. Indeed, one company that apparently ordered six machines in the two days after that meeting on 7 and 8 May states in paragraph 2.19: The strength of the rumours in the first few days of May concerning the likely Budget measure was one of the main reasons given for one buyer for ordering a total of six machines on 7 and 8 May 1998. So there were rumours. We were operating in an environment that was fairly highly charged. We were doing it to try to get the agreement of a profession. Sadly, in our taking them on trust, some members of that profession have very seriously let us down. In the whole of chapter 2 of the Auditor's report, he sets the environment in which we were operating. There were many discussions about such a proposal. This proposal had been anticipated since the Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee released its report in late 1997. I had said quite openly to people that I wanted to fund MRI. I could not see logically why we would not fund it. We were just somewhat daunted by how you put a new technology like this into the budget. Going through the early paragraphs in chapter 2, in almost each paragraph there is evidence that, from late March, there was discussion about supply measures-not discussion that I was in any way involved with, not discussion that was in any way improper. This was a negotiation authorised by cabinet for us to try to reach agreement on a whole range of measures with the profession. Just take for example paragraph 2.2, which says: College members would have expected the MBS benefits to become available for MRI services ... Paragraph 2.4 says: ... discussions of supply controls did take place within the Task Force and in its negotiations with the Commonwealth. Paragraph 2.5 says: By early April 1998, the Task Force and the Department were considering several control measures to prevent a blow-out of the diagnostic imaging expenditure. These measures included a ‘site freeze for a limited time'. Paragraph 2.6 says: The last measure, that is controlling supply through a site freeze, appears to have been discussed amongst the Task Force for the first time in late March/early April 1998. So six months before this meeting we were discussing site freezes. Paragraph 2.6 goes on to say: There are differing views on what College members considered to be a site freeze-but the essential aspect of it was a freeze on eligibility chines beyond a certain point in time. In essence, the type of control which was implemented. And it goes on and on. There was much discussion. This was clearly causing a great deal of anxiety amongst the radiologists who were used to getting open slather on something like this and wanted not to have any limitation on what they could do. So, in this environment where there was open discussion, we were attempting to negotiate an agreement. That is picked up by the Auditor himself in paragraph 2.32, which I think is the key paragraph-and I will talk about that in a moment. This is a difficult area because, as I said, we have not in the past had a lot of these sorts of negotiations with professional bodies. Perhaps governments in the future might be a little more hesitant to do it. Although I would say, having just had a lengthy and difficult negotiation with the Pharmacy Guild over a new five-year agreement, the department has operated in a way that shows that these deficiencies are not systemic and also that other professional bodies can actually behave properly and with some dignity and ethics. Well, what happened? Why was there this great rush for machines? The Labor Party makes much of the big rush in orders. I think it is very well explained in paragraph 2.32 where it says: ... when considered alongside the differing recollections of what happened at Task Force meetingsand there is a substantial difference in recollectionit is a reasonable judgement that negotiation and consultation with the College and open debate about supply controlsand here the Auditor is talking in the context of the whole chapter about what happened over a six-week periodprobably created an environment where some participants may have deduced, or become aware, that the Commonwealth was giving consideration to inclusion of machines on order. I think that is probably what happened. I think that is a logical explanation. That is very different from a budget leak. That is a negotiation process with a professional body, sanctioned by cabinet, to try to come to an of maoutcome. It is not some sort of secret meeting or something about which there is any impropriety at all. If you take into account the fact that we were discussing these things for six weeks, I think some people probably did work out what was likely to happen. The Leader of the Opposition asked, ‘Why would you have a $3 million punt if you were not sure of what was going to happen in the budget?' That is actually answered in paragraphs 2.61 and 2.62. I suspect he did not get that far. This is not any normal industry. You can buy a $3 million machine on no deposit and cancel an order at pretty much any time you like. So they were not taking a $3 million punt; they were doing something which had no risk whatsoever. On the other hand, there was a very substantial risk in doing nothing; so many people took the punt and bought machines, but did not have to pay a deposit and did not have to put down all the money. So this was the environment, and I think it explains the rush of orders more than adequately. The Leader of the Opposition made the point again that this information is so sensi- him: tive. Yes, I guess it was sensitive, but it had been openly discussed for over six weeks, as is chronicled in these meetings and in the Auditor-General's report, in meetings in which I was in no way involved. And it was obviously discussed at very great length long before it was put to me on 5 May as something that the government should do. In the end, ministers have to take responsibility. I am happy to take responsibility for providing better scans to the Australian public. I am happy to take responsibility for fixing the problem. But the Leader of the Opposition is suggesting that I have a standard of responsibility put on me that certainly in the past and certainly directly contradicts quotes that he himself has made. The Leader of the Opposition, I note, has not taken responsibility for the fact that, when he was Minister for Defence, he negotiated and signed a contract for submarines that gave us six submarines without a propeller that was working, with engines that did not work, with periscopes that did not work and with a firing system that needs replacing and is $1 billion over budget. I have not yet heard the Leader of the Opposition take responsibility for $23 billion in deficit in the two budgets in which he was Minister for Finance. The one comparison to this, I guess, is in 1985 or 1986 when Neal Blewett was Minister for Health, when you had Public Accounts Committee report No. 236 into fraud and overservicing in pathology. In some ways that was quite analagous because the introduction of Medicare and the lack of controls around the process led to great fraud and overservicing. In that case the Commonwealth did actually lose money. There was open fraud, there was overservicing and that led to substantial Commonwealth moneys being expended. Here there is no evidence that a single scan has been provided unnecessarily and there is no evidence that the Commonwealth or the taxpayer has paid a dollar unnecessarily. Neal Blewett was not required to resign after Public Accounts Committee report No. 236. Bob Collins was not required to resign with the fiasco over the granting of the pay TV licences. The Leader of the Opposition is on the record here. Let me quote ... when a Minister is obliged to resign, the Minister has to go for a reason, and the fact there have been difficulties with administration in the portfolio-albeit pointed out by the Auditor-General-is not, of itself, a reason and has never been. And he repeats it: Now, mistakes in administration have never been a basis for Ministers to go out. The fact is that this shows I have acted with the greatest probity. I have not been negligent. I have provided a great service to the Australian public. As for the mud that the Labor Party has attempted to throw, the allegations on my behaviour have in no way has not applied been proven.

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: CARE
text: Jagajaga) (4.09 p.m.)The truth has now come out in this Auditor General's report that we have been struggling for over the last 15 months. It has been like peeling off skins to get to the rotten core to find out the truth of this MRI scam scan, the biggest medical fraud that has ever been found in Australia's history. We now know that this Minister for Health and Aged Care, who has denied everything over the last 15 months-and of course continues to deny everything today-is actually the person who is the most responsible for this sorry saga. The minister is in total denial and is inventing quite a few things. We have just heard them at the end of his speech and we have heard them on radio and television over the last 24 hours. He suggests that the Auditor General's report cleared him of impropriety. I cannot find any reference in the Auditor General's report clearing him of anything. It does not clear him of impropriety, it does not clear him of negligence and it does not clear him of giving out the leak. In fact, what the Auditor-General says is that, whatever happened at the crucial meeting of 6 May, this resulted in the leak and the leak resulted in the scam. That is really what it all comes down to-a scam which has cost the health budget tens of millions of dollars and could have cost hundreds of millions of dollars if the whistle had not been blown. Of course, that is the critical thing: if the whistle had not been blown on this scam, this would have cost the country and the taxpayers millions and millions of dollars. There is no doubt whatsoever that the 6 May meeting is the critical one. The Auditor General's report confirms this. Last September in the House the minister called the meeting ‘an informal gathering' to thank the college. So they were just getting together to have a little bit of a chat. Now it has been revealed to have been a fully fledged negotiating meeting with cabinet authorisation. This came out very clearly this morningand the minister has gone from the chamber, so much for ministerial standards-when on ABC radio the minister was asked whether or not he had the authority to discuss issues about the budget night cut-off. He said: Well, I had the authority to do that. ‘I had the authority to go and negotiate on 6 May.' He said: I was authorised by Cabinet to negotiate. Then we look at the detail that we have not had before. That is why this Auditor General's report is so important and why this minister should be censured. We look at the detailed information that is in this report and see that three radiologists say that the minister raised the budget measure-raised the option that in fact became the budget decision-on the night of 6 May. The fourth radiologist says, ‘Yes, it was raised.' So four of them are saying, ‘Yes, it was raised,' three saying by the minister and the fourth saying he cannot recall whether it was the minister or a Commonwealth officer. The Auditor General goes on to say: This versionthat is the one that has been relayed by the four radiologists present. The Auditor General is not just relying on their version of events. This is very important because not only once again do we have the minister trying to shift the blame off himself on to what he calls these ‘deplorable radiologists' but he says everything that was done was done wrongly by them, nothing by him. He says: This version of eventsthis is at 2.28is strongly supported by the then incoming President of the College, who was briefed the next day about the meeting by the then President. So the then president had been present at the meeting of 6 May. He had heard the minister tell him about this option, that the government intended to cut off MRI rebates for machines on order on budget night. So not only do we have the evidence on oath from the four radiologists who were present at the meeting but also at the very important subsequent meeting by the outgoing president to the incoming president of the college this information was delivered by the minister. So we are not just relying on people who were present at the meeting; we are of course looking at what happened as a result of that meeting. That is a very important piece of information. It goes on to say: ... the Minister stated that he discussed the supply measures in general terms only ... Then there is a quote from the minister in the report: I can't say I didn't make a commentso he cannot say that he did not make a commentbut I didn't disclose the mechanism of supply ... This is what he keeps coming back to: he did not actually disclose the budget decision because, as the Leader of the Opposition indicated earlier, that decision was not formally made until 11 May. This is how we weave and wind our way around the truth. ‘The formal decision was not made until 11 May, so how could I possibly have disclosed a budget measure? But the fact is that I went in there and said, “Hey, guys, what do you think about the idea of restricting supply after budget night to machines on order? What do you think about that?” I did not tell them that this was a budget measure but I put this option to them.' This is what the radiologists remember, and this is what they passed on to their new president. The minister, of course, continues to try to blame the radiologists. He is constantly calling them ‘deplorable'. That is his favourite adjective for the radiologists. They have acted deplorably. I would like to ask the minister: how can radiologists act deplorably in a vacuum? If they did not know, they could not have let the minister down. And they let him down badly-remember that? He came in here and he said, ‘They have let me down badly. They have destroyed my trust.' Of course, if he had not told them anything, they could not have let him down. It was only because he told them that they acted deplorably; the two things go together. There is no question that they had information and that they went out and ordered these 33 machines in the next six days. If he said nothing at all, if he had not given them any indication, why would there have been 33 orders in the next four working days. Come on! One hundred million dollars of these radiologists' own money was invested. It was not someone else's money-it was their own money. They did that because they had been given the good old ‘nudge-nudge, winkwink' from this minister for health to let them know, ‘Well, this is what we're thinking of, guys. What do you think of that?' And off they went and spent $100 million ordering machines that they knew would then get Medicare rebates. In the short period of two years, as a result of getting those rebates, those machines would have been repaid. That is why this motion of censure is so important and why this minister should go, because this was a result of him letting it slip in that meeting or telling them on purpose-we will never know. Did he tell them on purpose, did he let it slip or was it just a bit of a nudge? Whichever way we go, all the evidence suggests that the issue was discussed at the meeting on 6 May. Having made such a botch of the negotiations, what did the minister do to protect the public interest? We know that he did nothing at the time, despite the department being aware that a buying spree had occurred. He was on the 7.30 Report last night with Kerry O'Brien, and he said: I was authorised by Cabinet to go and negotiate with the radiologists to explain what was happening. Now, some radiologists may have behaved in a quite improper manner out of thatonly if they had found something outand the Budget might have been exposed to some risk, but the fact is once we found that risk, managed it ... I have never heard a greater load of rubbish. The Auditor-General says that the department and the Health Insurance Commission did not effectively focus on the risks that emerged after the budget in terms of the unexpectedly large number of machines that were suddenly being ordered. So not only did the minister let slip what the budget decision was going to be but he exposed the budget to extraordinary risk and then did nothing about it. It is not just the Labor Party saying that anymore. This is the Auditor-General saying that the department and the Health Insurance Commission did not effectively focus on the risks that emerged after the budget. You will all remember this: it took an anonymous complaint, according to the Auditor-General's report-and we all know this as well-to force the investigation. It was not something that the minister initiated immediately-nothing could be further from the truth. He did nothing even though we also now know that his office received emails. We have seen an email to ‘Dear Mike and Ken'-that was from some mate-telling him that the shonk was on, but he did not take any notice of that. He did nothing when the department told him that there was a problem except to require purchasers to sign a statutory declaration-and we can tell that that did not stop the ordering. He did nothing to check on the department's performance when this was continually raised in Senate estimates. Instead, we have had 50 questions in the parliament to which he has denied that there was any problem. That is up until October 1999, when finally we got him to organise this Auditor-General's report. Thirty-three orders were placed in six days, compared to 15 in the previous two months. He continues to deny that there was a rush of orders in the week leading up to the budget. Remember that? We quoted that in question time today. ‘Oh, there had been a trickle of orders.' What we now know is that 33 orders were placed in the four days after his critical meeting with the radiologists up until budget night. Of course, he has accused the opposition of being sucked into a dispute between rival radiologists. Too right, there are rival radiolowe gists: the ones that were in the know and the ones that were not. And the ones that were not have been a bit annoyed-there is no doubt about that. They did not think that it was fair for them to find out after the budget that a few people had been in on the fix. Those people had been able to go and order their machines and get ahead of the game with this new technology. Now we see him entirely blaming the radiologists for their ‘deplorable' behaviour, blaming the department, blaming the Health Insurance Commission-blaming anybody but himself. I suppose it is really a bit ridiculous to even bother raising this issue, but we do have this guide on key elements of ministerial conductMr Martin-Junk that.

Title: CARE

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: CARE

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: CARE
text: The Minister for Health and Aged Care will not be resigning; in fact, he will continue to be one of the best health ministers Australia has had. I know that is a matter of great disappointment to the members of the opposition. The bottom line of this whole question of MRI is that we have delivered a better service to Australians. About 140,000 Australians have had the benefit of access to this new technology at a greatly reduced price, from about $700 to $50 or $60, so it has become an affordable technology to assist Australians grapple with their health problems. Furthermore, the waiting time for access to this new technology has been cut from about five months to about one week. No wonder the Labor Party are excited about this issue. The last thing they would want to talk about is the benefits of this new program to Australians, delivered by one of the great Australian health ministers in Michael Wooldridge. We flatly reject all these allegations. As I am duty bound, I have listened carefully to the claims made by the opposition. I do not mind saying that I have gone away and read the Auditor-General's report and attempted to understand the argument put by the opposition and to see the evidence that they have produced or otherwise. If we look very briefly for a summary of the allegations that they make, we need to do no more than turn to the censure motion. The censure motion is in fact very vaguely drafted, which is always a telltale sign. When you do not have any substance to throw, keep the thing as vague and general as you possibly can to give it a the bit of cover. There are three dot points to the censure motion. The first is: the clear evidencenote the word ‘clear'(both direct and corroborative)I think by corroborative they mean to include the evidence of the Leader of the Opposition just standing up and saying, ‘You are a liar,' which he did within the first eight or nine minutes of his speech today. That is their idea of evidence. The dot point reads: the clear evidence (both direct and corroborative) provided in the Auditor-General's report that he disclosed a budget proposal at a meeting on 6 May 1998, when he had a duty as a Commonwealth office holder not to do so; That is the main claim they make to back the censure motion and to back their claim that he should resign. I treat that allegation seriously, but there seems to be no explanation from the opposition for the fact that, when you read the Auditor-General's report, rather than there being evidence to support that claimMr Hardgrave-It is not there. It is the opposite.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: CARE
text: I thank the honourable member for saying that it is not there. The fact of the matter is that there is a clear statement of this issue and it is completely to the opposite. Why should you resign if the evidence is in fact completely contradicted by the very source of evidence which the opposition claims to rely upon? If you go to page 84, paragraph 2.27, it reads: All College members who attended the meeting of 6 May 1998 agree that the Minister did not reveal Budget measures. You could not get a clearer statement. I know what it is like to be in opposition. was in opposition for 11 years. When the other side are having a great week and you are having a dreadful week and you are trying to draft your speech for tonight's budget reply and you cannot think of anything to say, you are like a drowning man. If there is an Auditor-General's report for you to reach out for, you will try and give yourself a bit of political cover for what otherwise is an absolute disaster. You can imagine everyone sitting in the Leader of the Opposition's office with a computer each and they are all saying, ‘We will add up all the expenditures. Make sure the states get all the money, so we will have to find the money for that. Then, on top of that, we're going to have a bigger surplus, so we're not going to spend, we are actually going to saveMr Leo MCLeay- Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: CARE
text: We could move to a censure motion of the Leader of the Opposition, but I think we should at least allow him to give his vacuous speech first. But thank you for your advice on tactics, Leo. This is a serious point. These guys mount an attack on one of the best ministers in the government who has produced a great policy for the Australian people. They have produced what they say is evidence, and when you look to the document that is supposed to be a source of the evidence it says the absolute opposite. I have read paragraph 2.27. The answer to the question, ‘Was there a leak?' is answered in more than just 2.27. I have referred to that paragraph. Also, the Auditor-General found that all participants agreed that the minister did not discuss what measures would be in the budget. Furthermore, if you go to paragraph 2.32, there is an explanation in the I Auditor-General's view. Obviously the opposition want us to accept their view of the matter. They were the ones who were calling for an Auditor-General's report. The minister initiated the Auditor-General's report. He could not have been more open and transparent. He sent the matter off to the Auditor General. He gave evidence himself on oath. He has fronted up. After the question was raised, he made sure that there was no question that the Auditor-General had all the powers necessary to properly investigate the matter-we have not heard any of that argument again from the opposition-and when he does investigate the matter, it may be unfortunate for the opposition, but the Auditor General formed an opinion, a most unhelpful opinion, for the opposition. The opposition say, ‘It must have been this, it must have been that.' They have been whingeing and whining about this for 12 months. After interviewing 135 witnesses, the Auditor General says in paragraph 2.32: ... it is a reasonable judgement that negotiation in consultation with the College and open debate about supply controls probably create an environment where some participants have deduced, or become aware, that the Commonwealth was giving consideration to inclusion of machines on order. The fact is that for some time this was a matter of general public discussion. You could hardly be surprised about that. MRIs are new technology and people want to know whether or not the government was going to back it and make it available. Without being involved in it, you hardly have to be Einstein to work out that, when it comes to providing services to regional Australia, there is no government more keen or more interested in ensuring that Australians have access, wherever they live, to the best technology, particularly in the area of health. Whilst we are talking about MRIs, let me, amongst many others, compliment the minister on consistently pursuing this policy through to this year's budget in one of the greatest packages ever delivered for rural health in Australia. Government members-Hear, hear!

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: CARE
text: This was a matter of public discussion well before this matter was brought to a head in the way that it was. The other thing which is important to remember about the minister's conduct is that the minister acted pursuant to the authority of net decision. This was not a minister acting on a frolic of his own. This was a minister who had raised the matter properly in the processes of government and the cabinet backed him. The second point to make-and it is very clear if you read the documentation-is that the minister, as sensible ministers generally do, has looked to the expert advice in his department for the way in which to proceed. In fact, the minister attended the meeting on 6 May not at his own initiative but on the advice of the department, as a concluding meeting to a series of negotiations and discussions which had been managed by the department. When a minister acts in accordance with cabinet authority, when he acts in every reasonable way, as is clear from the Auditor-General's report, and when he acts in such a way which clearly provides a benefit, then it is very hard to understand why he ought to be the subject of a censure. Unlike the opposition, who have made these claims but when you look at them you cannot find anything to substantiate them, I make these claims based not on my own knowledge of it but on the knowledge on which the Auditor General's report is based. For honourable members who would like more information, the Audit Office put out a very useful little brochure to give you a summary of some of the facts and circumstances surrounding this. They refer to the fact that there was an agreement with the profession. In this brochure they say: The Department's negotiations with the College were successful in achieving this Agreement. ... Nevertheless, the Department believes that, given the underlying trends, the savings to Government have been significant; the Minister has supported the view that this is a substantial achievement. I am glad they have made that point because we have delivered a service and provided a saving to the taxpayer. That is a pretty good result. There are a lot of ministers who would dip their lid to the minister for achieving that result. It is true-I do not think we can avoid the fact-that there have been difficulties with the process. No-one walks away from that fact. The brochure summarises some of the views of the Auditor-General. It states: a cabiThe ANAO concluded that the Department's management of the probity arrangements surrounding the negotiations for the MRI measure was not adequate for the circumstances. ... Similarly, there were no agreed procedures or arrangements for declarations of any conflict of interest. ... This was primarily the responsibility of the Department. However, it also went on to say, just to ensure there is balance in this: It is important to observe that the Department met the formal requirements of the Budget processes and acted with proper authority to progress development of the measure. . . . . The Department's processes for developing the proposal to include machines on order before Budget night in the Budget measure, and in providing advice to the Minister on this matter, could have usefully involved greater consideration and attention to all relevant options. There have been inadequacies identified in the process. The minister has, however, acted within cabinet authority. He has sensibly relied on the department's advice. It is interesting that in this debate no-one in the opposition has actually referred to the benefits to the Australian public. Mr Laurie Ferguson-That is no justification.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: CARE
text: I hear the interjection, but in the end you have to look at the minister's conduct. The conduct of the minister was directed at achieving an objective, which was to improve health services for Australians and particularly to ensure accessibility of services to regional Australians. He was doing so within the context of a cabinet authority. He relied on departmental advice and he not only achieved an improvement in services but did so, following those negotiations, in a way which was beneficial to the taxpayer. As I said, there is no walking away from it: there were inadequacies in the process. But the opposition needs to specifically pin that on the minister. When you look at the conduct of the minister, it seems impossible to do so. In fact, as I read the Auditor General's report, there are basically no criticisms of the minister. There is no suggestion that the minister has acted without propriety. There is no suggestion that the minister has done anything other than act with the highest standards of probity. We would expect that of this minister because he is a person greatly respected on our side of politics, not only because he is an expert in health but also because he is a person of stature who has gained that respect by the quality of the work that he has done as a minister. What an embarrassment it was for the Leader of the Opposition when the minister, in his concluding remarks, referred to this central and remaining point-a quote from none other than the Leader of the Opposition, who said: But when a minister is obliged to resign, the minister has to go for a reason. The fact that there have been difficulties with administration in the portfolio, albeit pointed out by the AuditorGeneralyou could not get a more exact parallel than that reference there to the Auditor-Generalis not of itself a reason and never has been. Thank you, Leader of the Opposition. Knowing the speech you are going to give tonight, it is probably the only thing you are going to get right today-and it was a while ago since you got it right. This minister is highly respected. We think he has done a great job for Australia in the area of health. I believe that this censure motion should be the end of this matter. The opposition have been whingeing and whining, making up claims, misleading people and setting out to attack this minister without the evidence. They called for the evidence, the evidence has been produced and there is no evidence to back up all the whingeing, whining claims we have had for 12 months. We reject this censure motion, we support this minister and goodbye to the opposition. (Time expired) Question put: That the motion (Mr Beazley's) be agreed to. The House divided. Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: Flinders-Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business) (5.01 p.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. An enduring characteristic of the Howard coalition government has been our commitment to policy-making in the national interest. Our workplace relations policies are designed to benefit both the national interest and our workplaces as a whole, not narrow sectional interests. We are transforming what was for decades a centrally controlled industrial relations system into one where outcomes are put above process, where cooperation substitutes for backroom deals, and where agreements between employers and employees at the workplace level have primacy over the intervention of third parties. Two broad goals underpin these reforms. The first is to ensure that Australia has a workplace relations system that sustains and enhances our living standards, our jobs, our productivity and our international competitiveness. The second is to promote a more inclusive and cooperative workplace system, one that accepts the realities of a diverse, mobile and skilled labour force-where most employers and employees are capable of making agreements on wages, conditions and work and family responsibilities subject to a safety net of minimum standards. Achieving these goals has required structural reform to the system. As this week's budget papers noted, international authorities have recently concluded that ‘structural reforms have raised Australia's sustainable productivity growth, thereby enhancing the growth potential of the economy'. The result has been lower unemployment and jobs growth, with 699,600 new jobs created in workplaces since March 1996 and an unemployment rate today of 6.8 per cent-and the flow-on benefits to families from those new jobs. One of the structural reforms that has underpinned these outcomes is the system of genuine workplace or enterprise bargaining. The overwhelming majority of Australian employees in the workplace relations system are now employed under enterprise or workplace agreements-whether collective or individual, whether under federal or state laws. This system of enterprise bargaining has produced mutual benefits for workers, employers and the national interest on almost every criterion-better wages, relevant conditions, higher productivity, more jobs, increased competitiveness, greater workplace participation and lower dispute levels. It has been consistent with the economic and social goals already mentioned. Significantly, its outcomes have been far superior to those of the centrally controlled system that preceded it. Evidence that enterprise bargaining is central to the national interest lies in the fact that it has, since the early 1990s and until recently, been a policy attracting bipartisan political and industrial support at federal and state levels in every Australian jurisdiction. In fact it was the Keating Labor government and the ACTU that both adopted it as policy in their Accord Mark VI in 1990, and pursued it vigorously in industrial tribunals, legislatively and publicly. For all of the deficiencies of the Keating Labor government, for all of the inadequacies of the bargaining model implemented at that time, Labor knew what we all know-that the enterprise bargaining system was a structural reform in the national interest. Its importance is underscored in this week's budget papers which state the position clearly: ‘The strongest productivity growth in the private sector has also been in those industries dominated by enterprise bargaining-mining, finance and insurance and manufacturing' (Budget Strategy and Outlook 2000-01 Budget Paper No. 1). Yet the enterprise bargaining system is today under serious threat, politically and industrially. The ACTU leadership and certain unions have opportunistically turned their faces against it by supporting a return to industrywide pattern bargaining. Enterprise bargaining is the system where wages and conditions are determined by genuine negotiation at each enterprise through workplace participation by management, the workforce and their representatives, with outcomes based on local circumstances and mutual interests. Pattern bargaining on the other hand is the practice whereby unions demand common outcomes in respect of terms and conditions of employment across a swathe of employers or an industry in lieu of genuine enterprise bargaining, and then use the statutory protected action provisions to legitimise industrial action in pursuit of such claims. Pattern bargaining is designed to undermine Australia's successful enterprise bargaining system and return workplace relations outcomes to a centrally controlled onesize-fits-all approach. This is currently the case in one of Australia's major industry sectors-the manufacturing industry-an industry where business welfare and an employee's job security is closely allied to international competitiveness and productivity growth. Pattern bargaining is a manipulation of the legislative right to enterprise vided for by the Workplace Relations Act 1996 (the act), and by the previous Labor government's industrial legislation. Under pattern bargaining, union officials making backroom deals assume control over multiple outcomes, not by participative workplace negotiation involving local circumstances and those who have most at stake-employers and employees. This bill is essential to maintain the integrity of the enterprise bargaining system in Australia and its mutually beneficial outcomes. The coalition indicated in our 1998 workplace relations policy that we would improve the legislative framework to distinguish between protected action in pursuit of genuine bargaining, and illegitimate bargaining and related industrial action. We are now acting on that undertaking. Employers and employees have clearly embraced enterprise bargaining in the past decade. More than 17,000 collective agreements have been formalised under the federal system alone, with thousands more under state bargaining systems, as well as individual workplace agreements under federal and some state laws. More than 80 per cent of all federal award employees are covered by enterprise bargaining agreements. Agreements made directly between employers and their employees, with limited third party involvement, are becoming increasingly used as a vehicle for better wages and flexible and innovative employment conditions and work practices. Threats to enterprise agreements are not confined to the manufacturing industry. Manipulation of the legislative bargaining regime, if not contained, is capable of flowing on to other industry sectors where likeminded union officials seek to dictate wage and condition outcomes. The manufacturing industry campaign, which is already under way and will be escalating in Victoria from 1 July, presents a serious threat to the workplace relations system. Such an outcome would compromise many of the gains made in that and other sectors since the introduction of enterprise bargaining nearly a decade ago. It would not be in the national interest. This is a matter that calls for immediate rebargaining pro- medial legislation. The provisions contained in this bill will: qualify access to the right to take protected industrial action so that where, on application by a negotiating party, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission finds that a party is engaging in pattern bargaining (as defined) it must terminate the bargaining period, rendering industrial action unprotected at law; enhance the effectiveness of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission's power to issue orders that unlawful industrial action cease or not occur; give the Australian Industrial Relations Commission a power to order cooling off periods in respect of protected industrial action where this will assist the resolution of matters in dispute; protect existing rights to pursue common law remedies in response to unlawful industrial action in supreme courts without additional litigation in the form of anti-suit injunctions being sought from or issued by the Federal Court; and make other minor or technical amendments necessary for the effective operation of the industrial action and compliance provisions of the act. It is important to note that these substantive amendments in the bill relating to pattern bargaining, cooling-off periods and unprotected industrial action provide an important determinative role for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, as the independent arbiter on disputed matters. In this way, the bill recognises a proper and enhanced jurisdiction for the commission, in addition to its existing functions. Orders relating to unprotected industrial action. The present section 127 of the act was introduced to provide a timely remedy for parties affected by unprotected industrial action. This section empowers the commission to issue orders to stop or prevent industrial tion. Whilst section 127 has generally proved to be an effective mechanism, delays in the making or enforcement of section 127 orders have in some cases had the negative consequence of extending the period during which businesses are exposed to unprotected industrial action. The proposed amendments are designed to overcome these problems by amending the processes by which such orders are made. The new provisions will require the commission to deal with section 127 applications within 48 hours of their lodgement, including the determination of whether the industrial action is or is not protected action. If the application is unable to be determined within the 48 hours, the commission is required to issue an interim order to stop or prevent the industrial action, unless to do so would be contrary to the public interest. Industrial action and pattern bargaining The definition of pattern bargaining in the bill means that pattern bargaining is a course of conduct, bargaining or the making of claims in a campaign or part of a campaign that involves seeking common outcomes in respect of wages or other employment conditions. The commission must be satisfied that two elements exist: the conduct, bargaining or making of claims is part of a campaign that extends beyond a single business; and the conduct, bargaining or making of claims is contrary to the objective of encouraging genuine enterprise or workplace agreement making. A course of conduct or bargaining by an association of employees that extends beyond a single business is taken to be contrary to the objective of genuine enterprise bargaining unless the commission is satisfied that all of the common elements sought are of such a nature that they are not capable of being pursued at the single business level. An organisation of employees would not be considered to be engaged in pattern bargaining merely because it is seeking terms and conditions of employment which would give effect to a full bench decision establishac- ing national standards. This approach will ensure that bargaining, and in particular protected industrial action taken in support of bargaining, is focussed on mutually beneficial outcomes at the enterprise level. Limiting protected industrial action to persons directly involved Arising from the operation of the existing act, the government's attention has been drawn to circumstances where unions have sought to involve all their members who are employed by an employer negotiating an agreement in taking protected action irrespective of whether the employee would be subject to the proposed agreement. This is not the intention of the 1996 act. The bill proposes amendments that would ensure that protected action during negotiations for a certified agreement are only available to those to whom the proposed agreement will apply. In practice, the effect of these proposed changes will be that industrial action will not have immunity if it is taken in concert with any person or organisation of employees that is not protected in respect of industrial action being taken. Court to determine if action is protected action. The proposed provisions would expressly confer jurisdiction on the Federal Court to determine whether industrial action is protected, and, if so, whether the industrial action is covered by the immunity provided by the act. Although the Federal Court already has such jurisdiction, questions have arisen in the operation of the act as to whether its jurisdiction is exclusive of the jurisdiction of territory courts. The proposed amendments will clarify that the Federal Court's jurisdiction in respect of these matters is not exclusive. In addition, proposed provisions will protect existing rights to pursue common law remedies in response to unlawful industrial action in supreme courts without additional litigation in the form of anti-suit injunctions being sought from or issued by the Federal Court. Power to order cooling-off periods Under the existing statutory scheme, the commission has used existing provisions to order a form of cooling-off period to provide a circuit breaker during particularly difficult bargaining disputes. Such decisions have been made in the best interests of the parties and should be given specific statutory recognition. The bill does that. Under the proposed amendments, the commission would suspend a bargaining period for a specified period on request of one of the negotiating parties, if it were satisfied that the suspension would assist parties to resolve their differences, provided that the suspension would not be contrary to the public interest. Industrial action taken into a proposed agreement while the bargaining period is suspended would not be protected action. This bill is necessary to ensure that the legislative framework relating to enterprise bargaining and industrial action is properly meeting its intended objectives. Without this remedial legislation, the checks and balances in the system which regulate the rights and responsibilities of employers, employees, unions and employer associations will be undermined by illegitimate bargaining and immunity for illegitimate industrial action. That cannot and should not be allowed to occur. The national interest, as well as the mutually beneficial outcomes that the enterprise bargaining system is providing to Australian workplaces, must remain paramount. In introducing this bill, it is appropriate to note the persuasive evidence and submissions made by the Australian Industry Group and state or its members to the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Legislation Committee last September. In conjunction with other business organisations, the AI Group has clearly identified the need for this remedial legislative action in order to maintain the proper conduct of workplace relations in the manufacturing sector. I am therefore hopeful that this legislation will be in place by 1 July 2000. Before concluding, I should also acknowledge the constructive discussions the government has had with the Australian Democrats on this issue. In their minority Senate report last November, the Democrats indicated that government proposals at that time were deficient, but that the matter justified further consideration. This bill reflects a range of revised government proposals. Those revisions, while still addressing the problem of pattern bargaining and associated industrial action, take into account more fully both evidence given to the 1999 Senate committee, as well as the policy thrust of the Australian Democrats, particularly their concern for a proper role for the commission in these matters. I also wish to put on the record my appreciation of those within my own office and within the department who have worked assiduously to bring this bill to its relation presentation in the parliament today. I commend the bill to the House, and table the explanatory memorandum. Debate (on motion by Mr Griffin) adjourned. Speaker: Mr HOCKEY
Title: INDIRECT TAX LEGISLATION
text: I move: That the bill be now read a second time. In just over 50 days, Australia will see the implementation of the most significant tax reform since World War II, including the largest tax cuts in Australia's history. The reform package also includes large increases to family assistance, increases to pensions and all other government benefits, the abolition of wholesale sales tax and the introduction of the GST. As part of the implementation phase of the GST, the government has embarked upon an extensive information and community education program. Both the Australian Taxation Office and GST Start-Up Assistance Office have played key roles with comprehensive seminar programs, the provision of booklets and fact sheets on the operation of the GST, and several infolines addressing both tax issues and the business skills needed to prepare for tax reform. The Australian Taxation Office has also issued a large number of rulings on detailed operation of the law in relation to the GST. As a result of the detailed examination of the law through the rulings process, feedback received from taxpayers on the GST legislation, as well as comments from the New Tax System Advisory Board, several issues have been raised by interested parties including the need for amendments. The government has looked at the issues raised and considers that a number of amendments need to be made to ensure that the legislation remains consistent with the government's original intentions. The amendments in this bill will apply to the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act 1999, the GST act, and related legislation. They give effect to the measures announced in the Treasurer's press release No. 37, of 3 May 2000, as well as some other issues not previously announced. The measures in this bill cover approximately 30 minor policy issues and nine technical issues. The majority of the amendments are concessional in nature and will be welcomed by business. In addition, there are a small number of amendments which are regarded as anti-avoidance measures to ensure that aspects of the law operate as intended. The other amendments are technical in nature but are essential to ensure that the legislation operates effectively. Some of the more important amendments contained in this bill are as follows. This bill will amend the GST act to give the Commissioner of Taxation the power to issue guidelines to specify that certain fundraising events undertaken by charities can be treated as input taxed. These fundraising events could include a fete, ball, or other similar event that is separate from, nor forming part of, a series of similar events. Events involving the sale of small fundraising items such as badges, flowers and confectionery will be included provided the charitable entity is not in the business of selling such items. Where the fundraising event does not meet this description, the amendments provide that a charitable entity may make a request to the commissioner to apply his discretion to treat an activity as input taxed. In applying his discretion, the commissioner would need to have broad regard to whether the charitable entity is in the business of making such supplies. In addition, the commissioner must be satisfied that the fundraising is genuine and the proceeds are for the direct benefit of the charity. This bill amends the GST act to make the delivery of livestock to a processor a taxable supply. This confirms the government's policy in respect of food to ensure that, as far as practicable, farmers should be in a position to sell their produce subject to GST. This bill also amends the GST act to ensure the lease or hire of goods by preschools, primary schools and secondary schools to students are GST free provided the school retains property of those goods. These supplies will be GST free as long as there is not any transfer, or agreement to transfer ownership of the goods to any student or anyone else at any stage, and the supply must be directly and principally for use by that student in a GST-free education course supplied by the school. Other measures in this bill relate to: streamlined processes to let businesses inform insurance companies of their input tax credit status; allowing more flexible arrangements for accounting for GST for transactions between agents and principals; clarifying the GST treatment of supplies involving nonresidents; rules for calculating GST; taking borrowing out of the financial supplies de minimus threshold except for those borrowings that are related making financial supplies; applying consistent principles to GST turnover tests to assist and two revenue protection measures to prevent stockpiling of alcoholic beverages. The amendments in this bill demonstrate that the government is responding to consultations and is prepared to make changes necessary to ensure an effective tax system. Full details of the amendments in this bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum. I commend the bill and present the explanatory memorandum. Debate (on motion by Mr Griffin) adjourned. Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: INDIRECT TAX LEGISLATION
text: Fisher-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration) (5.23 p.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The bill will establish a new uniform penalties regime for all taxation laws administered by the commissioner. Under the current framework, penalty provisions are either duplicated or differ between different taxation laws and some tax shortfalls currently do not attract penalties. The existing framework needs to be modernised to cope with the requirements of the new tax system. The amendments in the bill will remove inconsistencies and will rectify deficiencies that exist in the current penalties framework. As a result, the new framework will be simpler, uniform and equitable. The bill will also make amendments to allow people other than registered tax agents to prepare or lodge a business activity statement on behalf of taxpayers and to give advice about the new tax system. Under the current law, mainly registered tax agents are to only able to undertake this work. Those who will be able to assist businesses with their obligations under the new tax syspubs and clubs; tem will include: members of recognised professional associations that represent accountants and tax practitioners; bookkeepers working under the direction of registered tax agents; and persons who provide payroll bureau services to employers. The bill makes a number of miscellaneous amendments to the provisions covering the pay-as-you-go arrangements, the business activity statement and general interest charge provisions to ensure a smooth transition to the new tax system on 1 July 2000. The bill also makes amendments to the Corporations Law consequential to the introduction of the pay-as-you-go withholding arrangements. The government has consulted the Ministerial Council for Corporations about these consequential amendments and the council has approved the amendments for introduction into parliament. Full details of the measures in this bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum. Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL
text: Fisher-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration) (5.26 p.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. This bill amends the income tax law to allow a beneficiary rebate in respect of the payment of the Community Development Employment Projects Scheme participant supplement. The supplement will also be covered to the pay-as-you-earn and pay-as-you-go withholding systems. The amendments will apply to payments made on or after 11 November 1999 and to assessments for the 1999-2000 year of income and all later years of income. These measures will allow the CDEP supplement to receive the same tax treatment as New Start and Youth Allowance supplements for recipients involved in labour market programs. To assist with the implementation of the goods and services tax, the government is providing direct assistance certificates to small and medium enterprises and to community sector bodies when they register for the GST. This bill amends the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to exempt from income tax any income attributable to GST direct assistance certificates. Full details of the measures in this bill contained in the explanatory memorandum. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum. Debate (on motion by Mr Griffin) adjourned.
